355ml bottle. Dark reddish brown shade. Short head. Aroma is toasted malts, molasses, light hops. Similar taste. Leans slightly towards a cherry and almond-like flavour. A smooth, creamy feel to the palate. Decent winter ale but nothing too exciting.

Pours cola red/brown with decent aerated ivory head. Sweet molasses aroma, with spices, cherries, dates. The taste is similar, with the spices quite pronounced. Light-med bodied. Pretty good but not great.
Awesome aroma of dark fruits and complex malts. Big thick head and silky smooth carbonation. Flavor of complexity took on life of its own of prune and toffee. Finishes of molasses and earthy hops.

Cloudy dark mahogany, yellow tan head. Burnt sugar, light spice, dark fruit. Light earthiness. Touch of spice and bitterness, plenty of sweetness. Medium body, lingering finish that strays towards bitter. Light effervescence, not to much in the way of carbonation. Good.
Nice aroma of some cherry and raisin along with well balanced malts. Has a plum flavor accompanied by a maple malt character and a rich finish.
Reddish pour. Sticky. Aroma is sweet cherry. Taste is the same. I need a few more characters.

355ml bottle. Clear, darkest ruby red colour with average to huge, thick, frothy, fairly lasting and lacing, ochre-ish beige head. Malty aroma with a cherry note. Taste is slightly sweet malty, fruity, notes of cherry, red berries, a minimally salty and peppery spicy touch, celery. Very clean wrought, soft and smooth palate.
12 oz bottle pours brown with a tan head. Aroma of malts, grains and some cocoa. Taste is sweet malts and a bittersweet finish.
Bottle pours a deep plummy red with an off white head. Sweet dried fruit aroma with a rich sweet malt. Sweet malty taste. Takes a long time for the slightly bittersweet finish. Full creamy paltry.
Bottle sample at a tasting at Maxs place. Thanks troubles. Pours orange deep with a beige head, aroma of apples, caramel, honey, flavor is bitter with bread, caramel, medium bodied.
Appearance is medium white head and amber color. Aroma is some spices. Taste is small hints of spices and hops mixed with a sweet malt. Overall just not memorable.
Bottle. Clear dark brown color, brown head. Nice aroma of toasted brownies. Taste is malted milk balls with light spice. Very tasty.

2/28 - Bottle. Nice reddish brown pour with good body. Not a strong smell, but malt and spices were noticeable. Nice pour and a very good taste of herbs and orange. Felt good going down and had a decent kick. Overall very good beer and Ill be seeking this out down the road.

Cervesa molt maltosa, té gust a caramel i a galeta, però també té un toc a espècies.
Cerveza muy maltosa, tiene sabor a caramelo y a galleta, pero también tiene un toque a especias.
お祭りウイン
Draft sample at Olympic. From notes. Loads of caramel, spices and dark fruits.

Draft pour deep copper with brown hue. Nose fairly muted, sweet malt, light spice. Taste similar to nose early, apple, toffee, light clove, followed by moderate bitter mid palate. . Longer bitter finish with slight revisit from the spice.

Tasted on 1/3/12 from a capped 12oz bottle. Pours clear dark ruby amber with a very thick but smooth khaki head that slowly recedes to a nice coat of even lace. The nose is malty and spiced with notes of caramel, cinnamon, clove, and a lightly fruity aroma as well. The flavor is more bitter with the spices more prevalent, with the same caramel and fruit from the nose. The body is medium with average carbonation and a long, lightly bitter spiced finish.

Versa di colore marrone scuro, torbido; schiuma color crema, aderente e di buona persistenza. Laroma è forte di malto, dolce, profumi di frutta scura (fichi, prugne), tostato. Al palato inizia con il caldo del malto, sapore tostato, sentori di biscotto; poi ancora caramello e speziature; nel finale fanno la loro comparsa note più amarognole, scorze di limone, note agrumate, il tutto condito da un buon bilanciamento dato dal luppolo. Corpo medio-pieno, media carbonazione.
bottle. Brown with one finger head. Some sweet caramel malt, spice and a bit of hops in the finish. Very slight booze warmth.

35cl bottle from Earth house.
Thin off white head. Clear amber pour. Quite herbal taste. Nicely done.

Bottle (saveurbieres). Brown clear. Malty, slight syrupy, dark bready aroma with a hint of herbs, citrus. Mouthfilling, smooth, light roasted, with nice bitters. Citrus, some pines there too. Very clean, flavourful, quite intensive too. Really nkce brown.. strong english. Nice malty flavourful.-- bb

04.26.15 best by.
Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a beer can glass on 11.19.14.

A: Caramel, cherry, and some tartness (cranberry?).

A: Off-white fizz for a head that recedes quickly. Opaque hazelnut color in spots of the body. Lots of see through red at the sides and bottom of the glass.

T: Cherry and caramel dominate. A very slight woodiness is subtle. 

P: Smooth with bubbles on the back end. 

O: It tastes a lot like cherry cola. It has a touch more caramel, though.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Maxs place. Thanks troubles. Clear deep reddish amber with a nice beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel and lots of dark fruits. Sweet flavor with malt, caramel, biscuits and dark fruits. Medium-bodied.
Orange sombre avec un grand col beige. Larôme du malt anglais sucré, houblons fruité, et un peu dépices. Le goût est similar, mais avec plus dépices. Plein du corps, et presque onctueux.

12 ounce bottle. Bright reddish copper color. Large creamy beige head. Nice clinging lace. Rich malt nose with notes of toasted nuts and cocoa. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor has a distinctive spicy hop bite with citrus notes. Nicely balanced dark malts and spicy hops make for a tasty holiday ale that stands apart from the traditional spiced ales. Very enjoyable.

A decent winter beer. Very malty and hoppy with a nice kind of sweet finish. Pours deep copper in cor with a light tan head. Had a draft pour at grafton. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Look: pours a dark Amber almost brown. Very clear. Light tan head. 
Smell: lots malt like a lager. Hops come through nicely. Pine. Citrus. Grapefruit. 
Taste: nice hop flavor. Orange and grapefruit. Like a smoked malt of some sort. Some spices coming out as it warms up.
Feel: dry in the back end. Nice bitterness all the way through. Medium carbonation.
Overall: not a traditional winter beer. But very refreshing. 
First drank: home 1/4/15
Vintage: 2014

Klares dunkel bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit einer ordentlichen beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr röstmalzig, reife Früchte, Gewürze, hopfig. Geschmack röstmalzig, bitter hopfig, reife Früchte, würzig, im Abgang weiterhin bitter würzig.

On tap at mad mex. A little better than expected. Was thinking this would be some holiday spice brew but its spiced notes are fairly subdued. Nice candy aroma. Looks like lighter colored root beer. Barely any co2 on the palate if any at all. On the tongue, this beer at first comes across quite strong and medicinal, then it eases up a little as the session continues. Yes, some type of spice in there but its well balanced. Not over the top. A little difficult for me but better than most holiday style brews.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Nice copper malt sweetnes with fairly agressive hop forward finish. English hop are subdued but very present. Nice winter seasonal.

At just on cool and into a snifter. Radiant, deepest ruby with fine, intermittent carbonation. Head rises up to a solid, two inch plume out the lip of the glass. Complex nose is dominated by sugary, stewed plums and rhubarb, top-soil, toffee brittle with hints of nutmeg, eucalypt gum, camphor and subtle mocha notes. Wow, this one is in overdrive on the palate. Meaty, chunky, biscuity malts with heavy woody and nutty notes. Malt is matched by tart, berry fruit and a weedy, herbaceous and grassy bitterness in back and melded finish that is oh so long. Carbonation is soft. Quite firm, overall dry and a little alcohol is evident. A mouthful of good ale.(12fl,Oz, BB 06/02/15, gift from family)

Elegánsan pörkölt, éretlen gyümölcsös komlóaromái kellemes bevezetőként szolgálnak egy téli este nyugodt körülmények között történő eltöltéséhez, kiegyensúlyozott illatok ezek, melyek vélhetően egy szintén igen összeszedett ízélménnyel párosulnak. E tekintetben sem okoz csalódást az ital, mint azt később megelégedéssel nyugtázhatjuk: komolyabb hangvételű, pörkölt maláta vaskos alapjain felépülő közepes test egy intenzíven komlós, száraz utóízzel. Érett szerkezete valóban megállja a helyét a zordabb esték kísérőjeként, az ünnepi időszak levezetéséhez is kielégítő eszköznek bizonyult.

The 2014 version isnt my favorite. It starts so nicely; dark brown pour with really thick tightly laced and creamy head that lasts. The aroma has heavily roasted malt with dark fruit like figs or prunes. I just wish it was stronger. The palate is great; slick and heavy. But the taste is just unbalanced for me. The cereal/biscuit malts and spices overwhelm the other flavors.There is some toffee, which is nice, but all of those things crowd out the roasted malt that I want at the center of the beer. It also tastes boozier than the 6.7% it is.

From a bottle. Pours opaque tawny brown with a bubbly beige head and lots of lacing. Tastes like toasted malt, Earth, dried fruits, light alcohol. Light body and low carbonation. Smells nutty, malty, earthy, and light booze.

Bottle. Pours mostly clear reddish brown with creamy beige head. Aroma is toasted and cereal malts, light fig, light spices, and faint woody notes. Flavor is malty and smooth with some caramel and dark fruit sweetness along with light hops and a good spice blend. Medium body and carbonation.

Pours a deep dark brown with good carbonation and a 1 finger brownish head. Has a nice deep toasty cereal and bready aroma, with hints of of molasses. Taste starts with that same warm maltiness with the tones of toasty and bready flavor with hints of biscuit throughout. Finishes with a crisp but not overbearing bitterness that warms the palate. Mouthfeel is a wet and moist feeling with no dryness. Overall this is a great winter ale and one I would go back to again and again

A nice red-brown garnet color with soapy lace. Smells of caramel malt, brown sugar, light spices and fruit. Medium body and course with mild spiced flavors like chicory, caramel malt, kilned grains, fruit, earthy and leafy hops. A nice winter celebration ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The least interesting beer Ive had from Deschutes since the brewery entered the Wisconsin market this year. Everything is just sorta average. Scent has a bit of fruit, maybe cherries?, the body is light, and the finish has a bit of bitterness. Other than that, with apologies to Gertrude Stein, theres not a lot of there there.
This dark reddish brown beer has a slightly sweet aroma like fruit cake. It has a smokey but still slightly sweet undertone. A very good holiday option.

Aroma is citrus, orange, clove and sweet malts. Taste is a light sweet graininess matched with a fresh bitterness. Well balanced overall. Body is a cloudy orange/gold with a thin pearl head that retains fairly well.

Bottle, deep brown Amber, foam leaves quick. Aroma is malty with dark fruit. Flavor is roasty, then lightly malty, with a hint of cinnamon and citrus rind. Palate is light, smooth, carbonation adequate. Finish is sweet. Overall excellent!

Btl pours a hazy dark reddish brown with a big frothy tan head that lingers leaving lots of lace on glass. Aromas of minerals, dark malt,brown sugar,dates, and cola. Tastes of sweet malt, caramel and earthy hops. Medium body, adequate carbonation, tingling mouthfeel and a dry slightly bitter finish. Nice easy drinking winter ale.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2014 Bottle pour. This is a festive treat! Pours a dark red, almost to brown color. Thin off white head with a small amount of lacing. The nose is English toffee and light clove. The spices here complement rather than overwhelm the palate. Definitely a complex winter seasonal - enough boozy heat and spice to make this a winter warmer but with plenty of other layers that allow for more balance and other pieces to fall into place. The toffee notes add a sweetness and brevity across the dark maltiness.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2016 12 oz bottle, Calgary, AB, Canada via Zyn. Hazy dark amber, prune raisin aroma without being overly ?Chrstmasey?. Balanced flavour, thick, with more prune and clove then broken up with a nice resin bitterness.
Pretty good seasonal ale. Always a fan of deschutes and their fine beers! Good

The Jubelale pours a maroonish, blood orange color with a thick frothy light tan head that lasts a long while The aroma is light spices mixed with dark fruit. The flavor is dark fruit initially with spice and a hint of pine. Overall this is a pretty nice beer.

Poured from bottle into a tulip glass. Deep, brown color with off white head and good lacing. A lot of great flavors in this one: coffee, caramel, syrup, and chocolate to name a few. Great holiday beer, would pick up another 6 pack for sure.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2015 Draft pour at Frankies. Pours an amber color with a foam head. Nutty malt aroma. Really nice holiday style ale. Creamy medium body. Really light spice, but definitely there. I?ll drink this again.
Update: true to my word.  Really rich, sweet malt heavy, much more than i remember.  Not the most balanced, but decent.  Good for one or two
Very enjoyable christmas Ale. This one is not too over the top. Good look, good taste, good beer.

2014 edition... Picked up a 6-pack tonight at the 16th St Albertsons.. but anymore this is a shelf staple in Boise this time of year... Times have changed. Poured into my Elysian Pumpkinfest goblet... 1 finger tan head... the brew is mostly clear deeeep amber/walnut.

The nose is nutty/dry toast and still bitter with a bit of EtOH and slight dark fruits..

Flavor begins with something that I associate with toffee, but it is still dry and fermented out.. good hop bitterness with some hoppy pithy bite too.. plenty of dark toast and some light cocoa maltiness to really balance and make for a really long finish. Not really any malt sweetness to speak of.

Medium/light body... light/medium bubble. Every year a winner.


**********************
2007 edition acquired at Albertons for about $1.30. Enjoyed from a standard shaker pint. 

Good pour ... perfectly clear light walnut and a long lasting lite tan head with fastastic long lasting head.

Milk chocolate and roasted chestnut aroma .... nice mix of hops to balance. Caramel and floral hops with complex bag of roasty malts.

Roasted malts and an interesting mix of citrus hops... not expected on a winter warmer, but sorta expected from Deschutes. Not a lot of maltiness, actually quite dry for the style .... low bitter hop and slight roasted grain finish .... Oooops there was an American hop burp.
12 oz bottle from Giant Eagle in Pittsburgh. Lots of spice with a medium body. Mystery ingredients all through it. Very good.

This beer is a winner. Remember it from previous years. It is a delicious and complex brew that tastes like they used some of the darker crystal malts. I did not detect a strong hop aroma but they are there my friend and they perfectly compliment the rich malt flavors. This beer is dark to look at, especially in a pub atmosphere, but it does not block out the sun like a Guiness or Belhaven Stout. This is a nice seasonal beer. And as a rule, Ive not recommended many or any seasonal beers short of some favorite Bavarian Oktobetfest delights. Deshutes does not make any mistakes. Next up is a Fresh Squeezed IPA.

Appearance is deep brown with ruby highlights and a quickly fading khaki foam cap. Aroma is caramel, cherry, chocolate, and a hint of peaty smoke. Taste is rich bready and toasty malt, with caramel and toffee. A sharp but balanced herbal hop bitterness helps balance. Mouthfeel is medium with a light carbonation. Finishes dry with a lingering bitterness and toasty malt. A much richer malt profile than a traditional English pale ale, but still a great beer.

Pours a dark ruby/brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma is caramel, bread, and earthy notes. Flavor is malt, earthy and bready notes, with caramel, cinnamon and other spices. Medium body with soft carbonation. Pretty good.

Bottle Chris brought from Ohio. Pours a clear red with a small cream colored head. Aromas of dried fruit, toast, orange peel, caramel, black coffee and a whiff of booze. Taste is baked apple, raisins and bread at the front rising to a firm citrus zest bitterness. That falls off at the end to a spicy, fruity finish. More spice in the aftertaste.

Dark Reddish Brown, Huge Tan Head, Lots OF Foamy Lacing. Earthy Hop Aroma. Taste About The Same: Malty, Very Earthy, Hop Bitter Finish. Medium Body. Too Earthy, It Over Powers The Rest. Drinkable But Its A Miss For Me. Worth A Try...

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Dark amber brown color, thick tan head, narrow bands of lace. Taste is earthy malt with dark candied fruit that turns bitter on the swallow, then allowing sweet to return, as well as the warm sense of alcohol. It works, but a little heavy for the overall taste.

12 ounce bottle poured into a teku. Pours a dark copper to amber with a khaki head of velvety lacing. The aroma is dry and earthy sweetness. The taste is woody and softly bitter. Lower carbonation, thicker mouthfeel.

Bottle from Woodmans in Waukesha. Pours a dark reddish with an off-white head. Aroma has stone fruits, bananas, candied fruits and spices. Taste is of candied fruits, sweet malts, some spices, and simple sugar. Heavily sweet malty. Medium bodied. Finishes sweet. Shrug? Malty, with candy. Likely solid for style. Not great to me. 13.4
On tap. caramel, black, cloudy, creamy, soft carbonation. Lovely mouth feel. Easy drinking, textures of rounded Xmas trees.

Bottle to glass. Pours a hazy, murky brown with thin khaki head. Aroma is caramel malts, honey, a faint fruitiness of rasins and cherries. A bit of pepper. Taste is malty, slightly sweet. Definite rasin and date flavors. Some earthy notes in the aftertaste. Palate is medium body, low carbonation. Overall an interesting beer, just not my favorite style.

12 oz. bottle. Appearance: finger of khaki brown head, diminishes quickly, burnt amber color through light, cloudy, good lace. Aroma: nut, caramel, light roast coffee, faint sweet fruit, light earthy yeast, floral and subdued orange citrus hops. Palate: medium-full body, average carbonation, dry finish, oily and sticky carbonation. Taste: mild sweetness at the front, settles in right after you swallow, and finishes with a light and lasting bitterness. Overall, very complex and deep. Very well done.

Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a large beige head. Nice aromas of caramel, spices, ginger and biscuit. Flavors of caramel, cinnamon, raisin, brown sugar and bready notes. Subtle hoppiness. Clean mouthfeel with slight oiliness. Pretty nice.

Pours from tap a nice red/brown with just a bit of white head. Not much aroma but whats there is earthy. Taste is a bit hoppy and very dry. Theres a woody aftertaste that lingers. Really nice carbonation and thickness.

Deschutes Jubelale has a medium, beige head, a rust-red, opaque appearance, and some lacing left behind. The aroma is of rich, full, fruit cake, dates, dried fruit, some alcohol, cocoa powder, and cookies. Taste is of all those elements, plus strong hop bitterness and dark bread crust. Mouthfeel is medium, and Deschutes Jubelale finishes on the dry side and sip-able. RJT

Poured from 12oz into a goblet. Medium-dark brown with a medium tan head. Nose is a mixed blend of sweet aromas and a bit of spice, quite busy, but oh so nice. Taste is on the sweet side, full bodied beer, nice, thick and a bit chewy. Good stuff for the holidays.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Nice looking clear orange brown brew wtih light tan head. Aroma is doughy earth and a little zesty spice. Taste is a great malty celebration that unfolds on the tongue like a lightshow unfolding before your eyes - sweet, earthy, dry spice, a final huzzah of mild hops at the end. very tasty.

On tap at Barrel House, pours a clear dark brownish red with a creamy tan head, aroma is very roasty with a ton of Carmel and malt with a little bit of spice, the flavor has a really sweet front end with lots of caramel in the finish, spices mixed in as well, not bad.
Really good winter ale. Pours a darish brown with a small beige head. Roasted malt wirh sweet sugar orange bitter.
UPDATED: OCT 4, 2016 At the French Market. Lovely stuff. Rich fruity ale, slightly spiced but not overly so, like a brown ale but with more boozeiness. Serving: Tap

12 oz bottle. Dark, deep brown with a red hue. Thick tan head, heavy lacing. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, berries, prune. Lots of chocolate, dark fruits, plums, spices, dark soil, humus. A touch of bitter hops. A bit of a sticky, filmy finish.

2014. Bottle into a tulip glass. Deep mahogany pour. Thick cream head. Aroma of vanilla, dark fruits, light coffe. Taste is creamy, lightly bitter, fruity, chocolate, light roasted coffe. Smooth finish. Pleasant, warming.

Bottle.

A- Malty, alcohol, subtle spice, caramel.

A- Deep mahogany color, clear liquid, tan head.

T- Malty, slight citrus, slight spice, subtle caramel, toasty, floral, slightly bitter, alcohol.

P- Medium body, thin texture, average carbonation, malty finish.

O- Was a little disappointed with this one. Didnt get really anything I was expecting from it or at least it was all very subtle. Mostly malty and a little underwhelming, but the color was gorgeous.
Deep reddish brown. Nose of spicy fruit and toasted caramel malt with citrus hops. Flavor is similar with dark fruit, toasted malt and citrus hops. Mild alcohol spice. Somewhat sticky.

An ok winter ale. Not balanced very well. Pours a beautiful deep red with a super thick tan head. Smells of cherries and caramel. Taste however is quite hoppy, with a bit of Malts in the finish. Tasted at the BevMo Holiday Beer Fest.
Draught. Smells sweet and malty, with hint of hops. Color is reddish brown. Taste is a balance of sweet and bitter, but sweet soon fades and leaves hop bitterness to linger.

12 oz. bottle from Whole Foods. The nose hints of floral hops and malt. The taste is hoppy with a distinct citrus bitterness on a rich malt base that makes for a bold flavor. Theres a subtle spiciness amid the richness with a hint of cloves just to remind that it is, after all, a holiday ale. Not skunky. Fairly dry, with the grapefruit bitterness lingering after the finish. Overall, a surprise I must say, a good surprise...
Malty. Mildly sweet. Hints of holiday spices. Mild tartness. Not bad. Some hop present too.
Pours good and dark and really has a smell of the holidays. Perfect for a cold night.

Bottle from radimd, many thanks. Dark amber brown color with huge off-white head. Malty aroma with dried fruits, cinnamon. Sweet dark malt, sweet berries, pecans, almond, caramel, cinnamon, light piney hops. Spicy hoppy bitter finish with notes of caramel. Enjoyable winter beer.
Pours a chestnut brown with off white head. Aroma is spice, sweet. Taste is sweet malty intro, with an even bittering and spices on the back end.
Great malt backbone on this one.... Aroma is earthy..... Medium bodied beer..... Very drinkable...... Will get again.

Bottle. Deep mahogany, creamy foam. Aroma of light malt syrup, Licorice, banana. Flavor reveals a surprising hoppiness along with tobacco, slight metallic off note. The sweetness of the smell and the bitterness of the flavor contrast nicely. Quite good.
Not overly enthusiastic about this one, but it not a bad showing from Deschutes. Does have some fruit cake elements going on, as is common with these things. Not bad, not great. 12oz bottle.

You never know what youll get out of Christmas beers. Some folks go the spiced rout and some just make a strong ale while others just do some random thing. I prefer this to fall where everyone just makes a shit spiced beer and calls it a day. This is some sort of strong malt-forward strong amber brew. I am not sure what style Id call it. It is a gorgeous beer w/ a dark amber color and an extremely creamy looking off white head. There is a touch of citrus rind and slightly piney gingerlike character to the nose from the hops which is backed up by a bit of toasted malt goodness. The texture is nice and creamy and just slightly rich and heavy which works well here but might be a bit much were this a bit more bitter. As it warms, dried fruit notes come out which compliments the sweetness implied by the malts. It finishes pretty dry though and drinks just about right for a beer of its gravity. I can get behind a beer like this w/ slightly higher than usual gravity but having enough flavor to justify it.

12 oz bottle pours dark brown with a red tint. Lots of thick foamy head. Malty aroma, a little sweet. Taste is caramel malts with a solid hop presence, Bread, toasty, and piney. A little spicy. Not bad.
Poured from bottle, nice malty beer, toast and caramel, lingering aftertaste of malt, poured dark clear, nice beer.

Pours a dark copperish, amber in color with a medium sized tan head. The aroma contains earthy malts, spices, toffee, raisins, and apples. It contains enough to give off somewhat of a holiday feel. The taste is very heavy in spices. There is apple, orange, raisin, bread, toffee, and some candyish impressions as well. There is some sweetness with a mild tart touch. The aftertaste is a lingering flavor of spices. Medium bodied, with a thicker texture, and some mild carbonation. Not bad for a holiday offering.

Very dark amber pour with inch or so of khaki head that dissipated quickly to a bit of suds. Scent of burnt brown sugar, a bit of spruce. Low carbonation, oily mouthfeel, dry finish. Taste is a bit sprucey, deep carmel malt, indistinguishable bitter toward finish and somewhat astringent. Average malty beer.

caramel, chocolate, nuts, toast, roasty, resin, floral, citrus, herbs, spruce, earthy, leather, alcohol, red, clear, tan foam, frothy, medium bitterness, light sweetness, medium body, dry,lively, average carbonation, long finish,

lively, bitter, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, hazy, brown, red

Paired with italian sausage lasagna. The bitterness countered the sweetness of the tomato and sausage. The beer had enough body to it to be balanced against the heavy cheeses within the lasagna. Not an expected pairing, but it worked.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2014 Pours a hazy deep copper red with a tan head. Not an overpowering aroma. Slightly hoppy. More malt character. Medium body. Slight warming feeling. Overall. Pretty good would drink again.
Very nice tasting ale. Malty as hell, some spice and wood with a slight fruit taste. Very tasty would drink again.

This is my 14th different Deschutes, and it is a good one. It releases a lot of English note, and it sustains a great buzz. It is not spicy at all like you would think for a seasonal ale, and it has a clean, dry finish. It will make you hungry for Texas pit-smoked bbq, but for those of you who dont have Texas pit-smoked bbq a slim jim may work. Its a great ale, and very inline with the seasonal celebration ales.Viva la de Schutes!!!

This is another tasty english strong. The aroma is toasty malt. Taste is toasted malt with a brand cereal type taste with just a bit of hops on the end. I just wish it had a little bit more body and richness and little less of the brand flakes flavor. Overall, its still very good.
Julie says Very nice mellow spice.   Mixes well has a touch of s melt smell taste good.    She gives a 3

Shared 12 oz. bottle poured to snifters, displaying a clear, deep copper hue, with off white/light tan head foam that reduced gradually to a thin ring & film, and left some dots & dashes of lacing on the glass. The nose was decent malt, fruit, and light spice, basically a blend of holiday cake/pudding variety, with light, syrupy sweetness. Light to medium bodied, with presentable carbonation, included moderate, earthy bitterness, and some alcohol, but came off a bit tame for a Strong Ale.

theres a lot going on in this bottle, and thats a good thing. Hoppier and more complex than expected, it tastes like a hoppy strong ale and ages like a scotch ale. weird. always at the top of my winter list."
2014 had on cask for the first time and it;s just a perfect beer for that. Dryhopped with Tettnanger hops. What a treat?!

12 oz bottle, poured into a pint glass at ~45 degrees F.

A: Pours a reddish-amber, and forms a thick, frothy tan head with an orange tint. The head lasts a good long while, and leaves some serious lacing on the glass while it does. Held to light, the beer is a hazy red-amber, with no visible bubbles rising anywhere.

S: Malt and spice greet one at the fore of the nose, with hints of something floral and piney beneath. The aroma is primarily toasted caramel malt and spices, however, mainly clove and nutmeg.

T: Floral and piney notes are confirmed in the taste, beneath caramel malt so heavily toasted that it is nearly all bitter, not so much sweet. The spice notes are subtle rather than bold, appearing as just hints of ginger and nutmeg, not so much clove. Some fruitiness is present, but only in the middle of a sip. Floral bitterness lingers a while after the finish.

M: Smooth, light-to-medium in body, with carbonation on the lower side.

O: A solid winter warmer of the brown ale variety. Id personally have preferred something with more spice emphasis and less floral-pine influence, though I am an admitted malthead. The body seemed a touch on the light side for a winter beer, and Id also have liked the malt to be less toasted bitter, to allow more sweetness in. Still, not a bad beer.
Sweet, malty dark Amber beer. Very limited hops. Wouldnt buy again. Not the best of their brews!
Dark brownish amber pour with thick khaki head. Malty aroma with some xmas spice. Tastes of raisin, plum, brown sugar, toffee, and nuts with some light spice. Pretty decent.

Aroma: Malts are mostly toasty with a little spice; jammy otherwise. Appearance: Dark amber pour with a foamy tan head that settles into a skin. Flavor: Fairly fruity up front, but jam comes off more like runts, especially banana runts, leading to a semi-sweet finish. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, soft carbonation, long finish. Overall: Wasnt really thrilled with this at all; when reading other reviewers, Im wondering if the beer was, for some reason, in less than stellar condition.
Loved this beer and ready for more winter ales! Spice, earthy and a bit hoppy. Nicely balanced.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2015 12oz bottle, from Dutchs. Dark brown red color, more on the opaque side. Good finger of khaki head, leaves great thicker lace. Looks pretty good. Medium plus body. Smooth, creamy lighter carbonation. Awesome creamy texture to this. Lightly slick. Great dark fruit, some vanilla, toasty malts, very light spice. Fantastic earthy hop balance. Hint of cocoa, cinnamon.  Modetate sweet taste, good light to moderate bitter taste. Fantastic english strong ale. Suprisingly easy-drinking. Doesnt try to be something its not. Very good! Much better than expected. Ended up killing this in like 5 minutes. 8/5/7/4/16 Update rate, 11/7/15: 12oz bottle, from Dutchs. Mostly clear dark red, kind of brown color. Thin khaki head, leaves decent lace. Nice dark fruit, toasty malt, touch of vanilla. Some spiciness. Medium to bigger body. Mild slick. Crisp, lighter to moderate carbonation. Bit more of a spicy edge here than I remember. Moderate to bigger bitter taste, mild spicy bite. Much spicier this year, as far as I can tell. A nice, hoppier english strong ale, and nice to enjoy with my reueben.. but not as quaffable as I remember.

12 oz bottle from Fred Meyer in Hillsboro, OR. Aroma is sweet and a bit nutty, with hints of toffee, biscuit, and mild fall spices. This beer has an incredible balance of malt, hops, and spices. Mouthfeel starts sweet, thick, and creamy, and finishes the same, but with a pleasant bitterness from the hops and a slight, strangely welcome astringency from the spices. Wow, this year?s batch is great!

Poured from a 12. Color is a beautiful chestnut brown. Very inviting! Comes off very easy on the spices but still there. I get a bit of "cola" taste to it, sweet but not overdone with the spices. It sounds like a weird description but it works very well!

This pours a medium brown color with a foamy, light brown head. The aroma is malty with a bit of spice. The flavor is very bold with malts and spice flavor. Fairly decent for the style of beer. It does leave a bit of a chalky after taste.
Spice, fruit cake, mild cocoa, roasty astringency, baked pear, bready. Meh as with prior years its overly spiced. Id start from scratch with this tired ass recipe.

Its only September... seems a bit early for a holiday beer. But, as usual, the 2014 Deschutes Jubelale is very good. Rich dark color, creamy head, roasted maltiness, lightly spiced, and balanced hops flavor. A delicious holiday ale... but seriously, Deschutes, at least wait until October next year, sheesh.

Draft. Aroma is a medium malt. Appearance is brown with some lacing. Taste is almost Belgian, but is a medium malt. Palate is a weird one. Overall, a decent beer, but not much to write home about. A Belgian brown is what it tastes like.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

6.7% ABV. Winter Ale.

Nice thick light brown head. Vanished quick enough.

Nose is redolent of sugar plums, rum raisins and fruitcake.

First mouthful is full of the muscled forearm of a strong ale. Nicely alcoholic without being unpleasant or rough. A first impression of oak ash leaving a nice warms feeling in the belly. A good vehicle for flavors that are reminiscent of cinnamon-laced hot cider, mulled wine, plum preserves, cranberry sauce, nutmeg and even a brief hint of cloves. Makes me want to have turkey. 

A bit of a flat-footed finish, but overall a nicely balanced ale.

Jubel 2014. Just released Sept 2014. 12 oz bottle. Being a local Bend resident, we always await the release of the newest Jubelale. Although Sept seems a little early for the winter beer, we drink it anyway! This year is a nice product for the upcoming cooler nights and winter days. The warmth fills your tummy. Now need to try it at the Pub on tap!
On tap at Scratch Bar. Rating from December 2013. Lots of spice in this beer. Perfect for a cold winters day but also went down well on a hot summers day.
Pours a nice amber color with white head. Spice, dark fruits, and sweetness on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes warm and earthy.

[5381-20130524] 12floz bottle. Toasted light floral herby aroma has a light candied fruit note. Clear, amber orange body with a medium-lasting foamy light tan head. Lightly smoked grains flavour. Medium body. Average. (6/3/6/3/12) 3.0
Overheard: "Should we be calling you Tripod?"

Ebonied ruby lil sauce up in here. Everyone seems to go bonkers for this. I dont get it. I mean its solid, but not "flip your wig" crazy good. If looks could be taste itd have a higher score. Whiff of molasses, maple, caramel and light spices. Taste is similar but a bit more nutty and slightly bitter but still sweet. Awesome cover art every year though.

From 355 ml bottle. Pours a mahogany brown with lighter honey highlights at the edge and a small cream coloured head. Aromas of dried fruit, toast, orange peel, dark caramel, black coffee and a whiff of booze. Taste is baked apple, raisins and dark bread at the front rising to a firm citrus zest bitterness. That falls off at the end to a spicy, fruity finish. More spice in the aftertaste. Nicely balanced and delicious.
Slowbeer bottle (3-May-2014) Sweet light fruit spicy malt aroma. Red brown colour, low head and sheet lace. Pepper spice herbal light malt flavour. Light malt herbal finish&pepper aftertaste.

Fruit herbal hop malt aroma. Brown colour poor head & lacing. Malt fruit spice flavour. Smooth palate .

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[Tap] Clear and dark brown in color. Dark fruit and caramel malts in the aroma. Taste is of molasses, toasted bread, figs, nutmeg and cranberry. Decent mouthfeel. A tasty winter beer. Tasting notes from 1/2014.
Tap. Pours an amber with a light tan head. Earthy hop and chocolate nose. Sweet flavor with hop aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours dark mahogany with a medium tan head. Aroma of caramel, fruit, roasted malts and earth. Flavor of roasted malts, caramel, toffee, dark fruit, earthy spices and had a dry and bitter finish. Medium bodied, creamy texture, light carbonation.

A- Pours a very dark brownish red hue with a nice, frothy, off white head.

S- Dark fruits, hints of spice

T- Starts out with dark fruit, raisin, prune and moves into roasted malt, bits of coffee with some mixed spices.

M- Creamy, medium bodied with medium/low carbonation.

D- Nice little winter warmer. Not my favorite but I wouldnt mind trying it again.

Pours a dark garnet color as advertised. Aroma is slight hops, malts and all kinds of spice. Reminds me of a winter night by the fire. Taste is spices up front, some mild malts and hops with a nutmeg and chicory finish. Mouth feel is smooth with a bit or carbonation. The spices change as it warms in your mouth.
very tasty stuff....taste is same as smell....fruit hops brown sugar...i will buy again and again.

Beige coloured head ruby pour mild carbonation aromas malts rich fruits sugar earthy notes port the flavours doughy rich fruit some dried citrus brown sugar port wine honey cinnamon molasses ginger liquorice not bad on the palate the finish some good tastes the fruits and sweet malts added spice tastes could have had more body but still very tasty

Bottle from 99 Bottles (Federal Way, WA). Sweet malty and spicy nose. Deep reddish brown color. Rich roast malt, licorice, cinnamon, and maybe peppermint. Medium body. Tasty, but a bit weak-flavored stuff for a winter ale. The overall spice profile comes across as something artificial or chemical. Tastes more like a spiced doppelbock. A disappointment, really.

Draft at Sprengers. Clear reddish brown with generous cap of off-white foam. Low cola and cookie spice aromas. Flavors are fronted by a sharp bitter with raisin, molasses, marmalade, and even licorice playing backup. Low pH and clean minerality make for a brief palate but for the longer resinous parts.

Big malt and caramel up front. Spices and thick and syrupy texture. Middle is moderately high lively carbonation. Brown sugar is there..bitterness kind of balances it out in the middle & finish. Not a big fan of this brew, but its a nice bold flavored sweet and spicy winter brew so I have to give it credit.

Pours a dark brown, almost red with a thick off white head. Aroma is fantastic. Notes of malt and sweet fruits. Can also smell the alcohol...but its such a pleasant smell. Unfortunately the taste was not as good as the aroma. It kind of reminds me of Orkneys Skullsplitter. Its bitter on the back end like a strong english ale. Man, is this beer thick in the mouth. Such a nice mouthfeel, thick and creamy. Its just maybe a tad bitter for me. Not a bad beer at all though.

Pours dark copper with a quickly fading head.
Nose shows liquorice, sour spices, confectionery, sweet malt and brown sugar.
Roasty flavours with an astringent herbal hit too. Some confectionery-like sweetness and more liquorice.
Carbonation is too high.

12 oz. bottle. Appearance: finger of khaki brown head, diminishes quickly, burnt amber color through light, cloudy, good lace. Aroma: nut, caramel, light roast coffee, faint sweet fruit, light earthy yeast, floral and subdued orange citrus hops. Palate: medium-full body, average carbonation, dry finish, oily and sticky carbonation. Taste: mild sweetness at the front, settles in right after you swallow, and finishes with a light and lasting bitterness. Overall, very complex and deep. Very well done.
On cask in Jackson WY at Thai Me Up. Pours a clear dark cola with a thick ecru head. Malty nose. Flavors of toffee with bitter grassy hops. Medium bodied. Bitter finish.

Reviewed from notes
She pours a fairly dark brown and leaves the same colored body with a white almost off white colored half finger head that dies to a small coating on the top of the body. Some spotty lacing is left.
The smell has a malty sort of caramel but kinda coming through in a bland sort of way. Still theres some toasty yet also somewhat burnt nuttiness, spice tries to come through but stays muted for the most part.
The taste has a bland earthy caramel nuttiness, malty nutty aftertaste, dry finish.
The palate has a medium body, fairly sessionable - as sessionable as a winter warmer can be. Carbonation is fairly smooth and good for the style, decent to me.
Overall, for the most part, I tend to like Deschutes a ton, but this one is honestly only average to me.
Pours dark brown. Aroma is of coffee, grain, and wine. Nice, full flavor- spice, caramel, wine, raisin, a little nutty, dried fruit. Very good.

2013 vintage. 12 oz bottle. Pours mahogany with full head. Aromas of toffee, malt extract, and golden raisins. Flavors of salt water taffy, raisin bread, and grass. Possibly some spice . Bitter finish with alcohol present. Recall 2012 being much better.

355ml bottle BB 05/11/14
Beautiful looking ruby body, decent clarity, with a dense creamy beige head topping of precedings.
Good intensity to the nose; rich crystal malt characters of roast nuts, burnt caramels and light charred bread layered with earthy hop spices and vinous plummy fruit esters.
Excellent weight to the palate; chewy, almost sticky malt texture. Subdued carbonation contributes to the lusciousness.
Palate packed full of rich malt; toffee, golden syrup, treacle, nuts, toast and a touch of cocoa. Finishes with an assertive bitterness, lingering notes of dried leafy herbs, earthy hops and red plum fruits.
A thoroughly enjoyable ale! Somewhere between an Esb and English barley wine; certainly ticks all of the boxes for showcasing tasty malts
dark brown with reddish hough and a light tan head. aroma of roasty malts and spice. flavor is roast, spice, and leather. medium carbonation.

Pours a chestnut brown with off white head. Aroma is spice, sweet. Taste is sweet malty intro, with an even bittering and spices on the back end. Slightly heavy mouthfeel and finishes with a raisiny aftertaste.
Dark amber/cider color; Medium body; Aroma of toasted malt, caramel/toffee, some hops, & spice; Flavor of slight roasted malt, caramel, hops, spice, some dark fruit, and nuts; Dry finish; Not bad.

Pours a dark hazy red with a creamy light tan head. On the nose, caramel, toffee, hot chocolate, a little cinnamon, some dark fruits, and hazelnut. A nice biscuity malt note on the taste, nice light spiciness, caramel, light coffee, and an earthy bitterness. Quite nice, I love when holiday beers dont bombard you with spice.
Pours a darker amber, with a nice thick cream colored head. Spicy with a bit of bitterness. Earthy, slightly nutty, with some woody tones. One of my favorite seasonals I have tried.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2015 12 oz bottle poured into a brandy snifter. A very potent sweet cherry aroma comes through first along with some other citrus notes in the background. As this aroma mellows out, some faint clove, cinnamon, and caramel notes arise - in turn, the sweet cherry smell becomes more of a cranberry apple juice aroma. It pours a deep, dark, and hazy mahogany color with a light tan, soap-like head that leaves some trace lacing along the glass. The initial taste is almost overwhelmingly sweet and tart (cherries come back to mind) with a noticeable, but light, bitterness. The initial tartness fades as the beer warms up and some toastiness, doughiness and spiciness come through - overcooked cinnamon apple muffins come to mind. It finishes with a lingering, but mild, bitterness that comes through as a very light burnt, woody flavor.
Poured from the tap. Hazy mahogany brown with minimal off white head. Aroma of dark fruit, toffee, sweet malt. Flavour is sweet malt and hops, little but of nuttiness. Medium body.

Deep garnet pour with a creamy/soapy off white/beige head and lots of sticky lacing .... great looking beer .... aroma of roasted malts, christmas spices, sweet almost spruce tipish/earthy and light fruity malts ..... taste is of roasted malts, christmas spices, sweet fruity malts, earthy and again almost has a spruce tip to it .... finish is lightly bitter and spicy and the mouthfeel is soft .... great holiday brew

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2015 Among all the seasonal offerings that line store shelves, Jubelale is a standout in every way. The beautiful bottle art is on par with the dark color of this ale, which is a work of art in itself. Aroma has fruit, booze, and spice. Taste has dark fruit, spicy hops, lightly-toasted malts, alcohol warmth, and a touch of sugar. This is the kind of ale that should be sipped at the end of a winter day. Its everything a holiday ale should be, and more.

pours ruby/brown with a medium tan head...nice lacing. aroma has light earthiness, fruity notes, mild spic and a hint of wood. flavor has earthy/woody bitterness, some roasted malt...almost faintly nutty...and a bit of spice...a bit all over the place but not in a bad way. mouthfeel is medium and the finish is dry and earthy/bitter/lightly spiced.

Bottle, 12C. Dark reddish amber with an inch of beige head. Aroma is fruity and earthy with raisins, prunes, chestnuts, mace, hints of chocolate. Quite silky texture. Malty and fruity with a melange of spices more prominent than suggested by the aroma. Dry and bitter enough at the end that the richness doesnt overstay its welcome. Good.
Bottle. Clear red brown with fine carbonation and a medium tan head. Toffee, yeast, light clove and faint resinous hop. Taste is dryly sweet. Medium body with a light syrupy feel.
Dark red. Lots going on here...several layers. Spices. Toffee. Citrus bitterness. Well done.
1/21/2012. On tap at the brewpub in Portland. Reddish brown with a tan head. Spicy and malty aromas with earthy and fruity notes. Good balance and complexity.

Pours a dark mahogany color with a tan head and ample lacing. Aroma of roast malt, nutty and a hint of dark chocolate and dark fruit. Taste of roasted malt, coffee, nutty with hint of chocolate and spice. Has a malty bitterness with a finish that is quite dry. Medium body, quite smooth and nicely balanced. Nice winter beer but needs a bit of a kick to be a good English Strong Ale.
Pours a dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, fruit like plums and some spices. Taste is medium to high sweet leading to a smooth sweet fruity finish. Great stuff.
Dark Red colour. Strong malt character with some hints of spice. Will have to try this in winter. Was not the best pick for a 30C day in Australia.

Ah Jubelale, each year you come back for the holidays and each year I happily buy you. On tap in the bar, in the keggerator, in a bottle all of your ways please me and my friends too. Even my dad likes you.
On tap Park Hotel Werribee malty aroma with the hint of good dark brown with off white head taste is malty you can taste the alcohol no good in the taste

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2013 This is a hearty winter ale. The initial taste and aroma is malty. It has an intriguing fruity/spicy taste with a strong taste of hops as it goes down.  Not a bad choice for a winter beer.
Very nice. A lot of malt and a bit of alcohol warmth, even thought the contents not that high. Lots of malt with a spicy hop finish. Wish Id bought more.

Pours a reddish amber with a khaki head. Malt, biscuit, earthy hop, chocolate and spice aroma. Sweet malt, biscuit, caramel, chocolate and light spice flavor. Medium body and carbonation. Malt and slightly bitter finish.

Quite different for a winter ale. Cool reddish pour w/ a big foamy head that leaves lacing. Aroma is well blended concoction of malt, hop, & some spice. Unfortunately I dont get much spice at all in the flavor. Its malt heavy upfront & finishes w/ bitterness. Its solid!

Rating #797 - December 2, 2013 - 8oz on tap at Beer Revolution. Opaque brown pour with a bubbly tan foam that dissipates rather quickly. Aroma is bold, earthy, clove, nutmeg, turmeric. Lightly carbonated. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium-full bodied, this packs a punch. Strong alcohol character balanced by the gentle bitterness of the zesty, earthy hops. Hint of toffee and chocolate, plum, raisin, allspice. Absolutely superb.

Nice mahogany color with a creamy tan head manages to sell me that this brew could actually resemble an english strong ale, combined with the bready-dominated nose. Taste is richly malty, a little nutty, some mild spice, just a touch of citrus, and nicely balanced by reasonable hopping. Not a bad year for this seasonal brew (which is a bit different every year).
Very nice beverage for the winter season.Good balance of malt, hops and spices.
Bottle. Taste is a warming blend of roasted nuts, malt, earth and baking spice. Very nice.
Nice lot of complexity. A good, nutty brown ale. From the hand-pump at the Wheaty. xxx
Nice of white head taste really good, citrus one of the better beers I have found at Wal-Mart
Chestnut brown pour with aroma of caramel, dark fruit, and spice. Sweet malt flavor with caramel, dark fruit, chicory, and spice. Nice beer.

Draft. Not a bad beer, just nothin I was overwhelmed about. Had a nice head. Just not enough body for me

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Review #400 and this is definitely worthy.12oz. bottle pours a reddish copper color with a medium fluffy off white head that leaves great lacing. Smells of citrus, caramel, dark fruit and roasted malt. Tastes of all the same things in the smell and also noticed the chicory the used in the finish. Mouthfeel is smooth and chewy with medium to light carbonation and a semi dry finish. This is one of my favorite winter warmers. Very complex, balanced, and full of great flavor. I also like the artwork that changes every year.

This is very nice. Surprisingly translucent pour, copper in color. No hops. Strong malt bill. Christmassy spices perfectly in balance. A-

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at Deschutes, Portland. Colour is clear reddish copper with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, sweetness, caramel and malts.
Nice malty caramel aroma, not to strong. Pours clear ruby with a thin tan head. Great caramel and spice flavor with a bitter finish.

Tap - small foamy head, dark amber color, malty aroma and flavor, mild spice (expected more but it is very well balanced for a winter beer which is good), slight roasty character, really good overall

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear garnet pour with a 1 finger, yellow-beige head. Aroma is toast, toffee, biscuit, dark fruit, tree fruit, juniper, herbal, spicy and fruity hops. Flavor is earthy spice, hazelnut heavy nutty notes and earthy peppers up front, dark toffee, then wine simmered dark fruit, juniper-pine notes, husky grain, sorghum sweetness and herbal hops. Medium body with a creamy, maybe slightly slimy feel and light carbonation. Pretty good overall, but after one or two I am ready to move on to something else, something about it is just fatiguing to the palate.
Bottle. Pours copper with off-white head. Nose is pear, floral, caramel. Pear really comes out in the flavour with caramel and earthiness. Really liked the pear qualities in this one.

We did a blind taste test between this and 4 other Winter Seasonals to objectively determine which one was best. They beers were: Deschutes Jubelale, Anderson Valley Boont Winter Solstice, Big Sky Powder Hound, Alaskan Winter Ale, and Redhook Winterhook. Check it out:

http://youtu.be/TJowachG1no
Interesting diversion. Odd (but good) flavors reminiscent of ginger and other spices. Would choose over Blvds Nutcracker if ABV was higher.
Bottle poured into a shaker pint. clear brown taste is a raisen and malt, went back on forth with one still not sure if I like it. With have to try it again

Best by 12MAR13
Pours a nice dark cherry hued mahogany with a sheet of light tan foam. Smells of sweet malt, hints of nougat and ginger a bit of vanilla and graham, decent nose. Flavor is of dry, roasted malts with some coffee, some leather, some bitterness and a hint of rye bread. Medium bodied with limited carb and a slick, yet dry on acrid finish. Interesting beer, not sure Im a huge fan yet.

Best by 24FEB12 - reviewed 13NOV11 - 3/3/3/3/3
A: a cherry red beer pours with a finger of tan pink foam and excellent clarity. Spotty lace. 
S: Sharp hops and sweet malts with a bit of nutmeg and cinnamon. 
T: hmm the yeast is no good and too strong to me. Some metallic flavors, some astringency. Meh.
M: thin with moderate carb. Semi dry finish. 
O: well, not my favorite. Not bad.

Serving type: bottle

10-09-2012
Bottle into glass, pours clear brown wih kacki head, taste is a strong males, raisen, nice clean finbish, overall I like it

Pours a dark copper with tan head. Aromas of caramel, toffee, and dark fruit (plums). Very sticky mouthfeel. Very malt forward picking up the more earthy notes. Slight hop bitterness in the middle with an ever lingering sweet fruit/toffee finish. Flavors cling to the roof of the mouth and very slowly dissipate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From the bottle, pours mahogany with a small white head. Good lacing on the glass. Aroma and flavor of caramel and malts, some spice but not too forward, moderately sweet with only some bitterness. Good carbonation. A good easy to drink ale.

Draft at Alla Spina. Pours a murky maroonish brown with frothy beige head and nice lace. Nose of caramel, dark fruit, roast, dried fruits, chocolate. Medium body. Malty flavor with notes of dark and dried fruits. Pretty decent seasonal

Reddish brown color. Nice malty caramel aroma. Taste is roasted malt a little coffee, caramel. Some good hop flavors in the middle with a lingering bitter finish. Not as sweet as I expected. Nice beer.

Part of a mixed sixer at Albertsons in Vegas. Pours a clean copper colour with a big off-white head, great retention and loads of lacing. Beautiful nose with lots going on. Spicy aromas with chocolate malts and hints of bubblegum. With time, hops come out. Smooth, slightly sticky mouthfeel. Flavours are of roasted malts, caramel, grassy hops and again, feels like bubblegum. Quite an interesting brew that does well for christmas.

Bottle. Nose is darker and maltier than I anticipated, with some chocolate notes coming through underneath, and a little bit of nutmeg and fig over top. Taste is actually pretty well balanced, neither sweet nor bitter, but with the spice palate of it being very forward throughout the drink. One of the more pleasurable winter ales Ive had.

Bottle. Pours a dark muddy brown color with a creamy java head. Nose is sweet, with malty and caramel notes. Taste is sweet and fruity and full of flavor with the same malty, caramel toffee flavors. Finishes on the palate very smoothly. Nice ESA. Quaff Score 8 / 10

Pours a red brown with a tan head and aroma of caramel, toffee, and dried fruits. Well balanced hops and toasty malt with dried fruits, spices, caramel, and toffee with a toasty, spice filled mouthful leading to a toasty, sweet caramel toffee finish. Really nice English strong ale

Bottle. Clear, dark reddish brown with a frothy tan head that laces down the sides. Aromas of toffee, toasted sugar, and light coco. Flavor is sweet toffee, coco, light fruit and spice. Medium bodied.
Darker than I expected, with a slight coffee aroma. Taste is nicely balanced toasted malt & citrus hops with a sweet aftertaste

Tap (on nitro) at the Mill Northeast. Bar top color (dark mahogany) and a beautiful appearance in the glass. Mild aroma which is surprising from this one. I feel like the nitro muted some of the flavor and mouthfeel. Still a pretty good winter beer option. Not overly heavy but warms the soul. If its the day after Thanksgiving, youll be happy. Just maybe search out non-nitro.
Mmm good. Pours a dark brown, great head that lasts. Nice fruity coffe smell. Spices are there, chocolate is there... Great festive ale.

Wow tons of chocolate and fruits like cherry or plum, also chicory coffee in the amber pour with generous head.. A winner for Thanksgiving to beat the chill

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz brown bottle. Dark red brown pour with a few fingers worth of tan foam on top that settle into a steady thin creamy layer. Lots of thick bands of lacing left in the glass. Nose has light spice, chocolate malt. Taste has some spice, earth, wood, dark chocolate. Finishes with earthy notes, dark chocolate, some bitterness and a bit of a toasty note. Overall, a very nice looking beer in the glass from first pour to then end, drinkable, but with enough complexity to keep you coming back.

If I had rated this a few years ago I would not have been so happy about it. Since the lable changes each year I buy this each year for the bottle to go in my collection. In years past I have not liked it as much but either the brewery is workin on the ingredients or I am developing a taste for it. This year is good. Lots of caramel malt flavors with some spicy hop notes in there. Little alcohol twang to it. Like it and will probalby buy some more this year when it goes on sale.

From bottle to glass! Aroma is sweet like chocolate and malts. Color is ruby with a tan head. Taste is of malts and spice .

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

JubelFAIL...whats up with 2013 Jubelale? Its more or less (more) bottled foam, wont pour, overflows half the bottle upon opening. Bought a 12 pack at Sams in Fairbanks, whole pack was exploding foam. Went to local beer store (Goldhill Liquor) bought another six pack, same thing. Pop the cap and it overflows half or more of its contents. Try as you might to pour the rest, even after sitting for a while and it fills the glass with foam and eventually subsides into flat crud. Anyone else have this issue with the new batch?

Pours a ruby brown when held to the natural light and a perfect garnet when held to the indoor light. Has some honey gold and brown hues and good clarity. A fat khaki head of foam that falls like a lazy Sunday morning. Laces like it means to with rings and patches. Nose is malty and sweet. Some lightly sweet chocolate and dark fruit. Some spice and some earthy leafy depth. Has a little cinnamon and nutmeg but they are blended so well that its hard to pick them out. Taste is dynamite. The malt is perfection and smooth and full but not too heavy. The chocolate is less powerful in the taste and the earth and grain from the roast comes to the forefront. I love how this beer has a roasted quality that comes right to the edge of where it would have become bold and impudent like a stout but stopped gently. It has grain in the taste and thats how well done it is. The fruit takes a back seat but sweetens this beer subtly and without too much fanfare for a pleasant and mild flavor overall. The mouthfeel is excellent and the hops show off a touch of bitter alongside a bit of bitter from the roast in the finish that I thought was especially festive. has a nice gentle warming from the alcohol and a slight dryness in the finish. This beer because of its earthy nature doesnt have to stay on the desert or on the after table. You could serve this with plenty of foods. 

Cheers and thanks Bill for the chance to try this fine beer.
Very good winter ale. Nice and dark, hits the palate with all my winter expectations. I recommend trying.
Appearance is dark red or ruby. Slight brown head with lingering lace. Aroma is roasty. Taste is toasted malt with a balanced hop finish. Very good beer
Pretty good. Pours an amber/brown. Not much on the aroma..a touch of chocolate and malts. Toasty malt flavors with some spice and decent lacing.

Another winner from Deschutes. This one is beautiful, ruby red with a lacing head. The aroma is malty sweet with a hint of oak. The flavor has the sweet malt, some caramel and a very nice hop balance. Very smooth and tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark reddish brown, good head formation. Vanilla/banana aroma, mild spice. Caramel and banana custard flavor with a balancing nutty and roasted dryness. Nice complexity and balance.

Vibrant mahogany body flashing amber highlights, off white head leaving dense lace, aromas and flavors of lightly drizzled French toast with a touch of cherry and very soft hop spice on a smooth, pleasant body creating a slightly sticky residual

12oz bottle best by 04/20/14, about a month since bottling
Great aroma. A little roastyness, followed by some sweetness and dries off nicely. Gives a little less then I'd like but is still delicious for the winter weather.

Bottled. Pours an orange amber with an orange-tan head. The aroma is mild, I get spices and some malts. The taste is spicy as well, hoppy and malty in the finish. Overall spicy and complex, I like it.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours reddish brown with super thick off-white head. Aroma is sweet oaky nutty caramel malt. Taste is big lightly roasty caramel malt with a well-balanced bitter aromatic hoppy finish. Rich, sweet lightly spiced earthy strong malt drives the flavor. Tried a 2012 version just before and this ages well. The light hop notes fade but it develops a nice dark oaky flavor. A winter classic, one to look forward to every year.

Pours a very dark amber/brown with a creamy off white head. Nice lacing. Aroma is sweet and hoppy. Flavor of of caramel and tobacco. Slight toast on the finish. Smooth and medium bodied. Overall good.

Sample from Wegmans. Pours a murky brownish color with a medium sized tan head. The aroma has notes of nutmeg, cinnamon, and some fruity esters. The taste is nutty, earthy, a bit spicy on the finish. Its a bit early in the season but a solid brew.

Pours a big three fingers of head on a dark copper colored body.
The aroma is strong on the caramel with some lemon, toffee and milk chocolate too. Quite a nice mixture.
The taste is caramel and toffee sweet, with a little lemon and pine bitterness. 
The texture is medium body with moderate carbonation.
Its got great aroma and a wonderful flavor.
Black pour from draft at blackfinn. Tons of off white creamy head. Nutty and chocolate taste. Fig apricot and sweet taste. Slight whiskey notes. Pretty good and unique

Dark red brown pour some tan head. Aroma of woody leather nuts slight citrus co2. Rich woody malty soy sauce flavor. Watery strong carb slight acrid. Mid bitter finish piney hops. A good one, but could use slightly more body and less carbonation.

Draft, Parkers. Dark brown. Poured too cold to get much aroma, but no matter, this tastes outstanding, winter and holidays in a pint glass. Dark chocolate, tree bark, cinnamon, licorice, all held together with piney hops. Sweet, creamy, well balanced. Harmonious complexity.
Tap. Full creamy head. Dark oak color. Creamy taste. Malty to start, then sweet tobacco fruit. A holiday delight to warm the senses.

Dark brownish amber copper. Frothy kaki head,rich thick lace. Clear. Malty mainly caramel aroma with mild mellow notes of chocolate and roast. Fullish body malty, carmel-dark caramel, chocolate, fairly hoppy piney and bitter with linger. Bitter pine bite. Tangy astringent finish. Some dryness.
Smooth drinking ale with really solid spices and bold dark fruit nuances. Good on a cold winter day
A medium bodied beer. A very dark red pour with a somewhat creamy tan head. Light aromas with a nice balance of malt and hops.

Bottle-really nice flavor. Chocolate initially and then an ale taste. Really delicious. Love anything Deschutes
