Bottle. Very earthy aroma with hints of caramel and dried fruit. Pours garnet colored with a tan head and good lacing. Earthy taste with dark fruit and caramel notes. Finishes dry and slightly bitter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle poured a deep copper-brown hue w/ big frothy beige head a a little sticky lacing. Mild roast aroma. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a moderate bitter finish. Tastes are earthy lightly roasted malts, orange citrus, and light spices. Medium bodied, watery mouthfeel, and average carbonation.

smells of caramel and raisin. dark like a syrup. taste much like a belgian triple but doesnt try to be overwhelming sweet and complex. good bittering hops that are straightforward without being citrusy. pleasantly warming without a burning on the lips.
Pours with a thick lasting head, nearly red in color. Taste is far beyond aroma. Much hoppier than I expected
12oz bottle from a BYO. I like it ok and will probably buy some again in the future. Full bodied and perfect for a cold night outside.
Bottle. Deep amber color with a decent tan head. Some lace. Aroma is a sweet, caramel, dried fruit smell. Taste is a toasty almost burnt sugar taste with hints of mild hops. Good stuff.

Nicely crafted winter ale, pours dark brown / ruby red with beige head and lots of sticky lacing. Heady aroma of malt, oak barrel, peat and spice. Taste is malt, raisins, nutmeg and peat. Spicy lingering finish. Good stuff.

Bottle. Ruby brown pour with beige head. Calm malt aroma with a bit of spice and raisin. Nice mouthfeel with a tart raisin balanced with caramel malt.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours clear and has the color of a dark ale. Nice creamy taste a very well rounded ale

Nice aroma of raisins, molasses and sweet malt. Reddish ebony color, with a huge thick tan head, lasts forever. Muted sweet flavor in front. Balance of dark chocolate, coffee, and spice notes. Finishes with a sweet malt blast, then a mellow, porter like bitterness that ends pleasantly and dry. Medium mouth feel. One of the better winter seasonals out there.

Im not a big English ale fan, but Im expanding my horizons. Very malty on the aroma and taste with English hops by very obvious. Very earthy and warming. If youre a fan of the style, Im pretty sure youll really enjoy this one.

Bottle, pours a deep ruby body with a thick, light brown head. Aroma of malts, dark fruit, plum/prune, spices, and faint hops. Taste is similar with a more pronounced bitter hop flavor. Smooth mouthfeel with a bitter licorice and hip finish.

2013. THIS brings me joy in a way that comes around, well, once a year. I look forward to Jubelale far more than my birthday, daylight savings time (fall back, of course) and Christmas all put together and wrapped with a giant bow. THIS moves me like few beers ever have, remarkably, year after year after year. Always different from what I remember, always special. THIS floats my boat. Fruit, spice, something resiney in the background, something dark, roasty, lovely, and bready lurking around, a hard sweet flavor that is positively spatial, and a smooth, silky mouthfeel that goes on for a long, sweet, pleasurable ride. This is a treasure I buy by the case every year. Simply magical.

Would I drink again? oh hell yes.

Would I order again? and again, and again, and again.
Poured a beautiful brownish red with a tan head. Great tasting beer with a nice hoppy finish.

Malty light vanilla or cream aroma. Darker amber in color with a brown creamy head. Smooth feel with a light zest to the sides of the tongue but over all a great balance of malt, nuts and cream. Damn good.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2013 Aroma of Christmas or Thanksgiving potpourri, pours a clear but dark amber-red with a small beige head. A thick, malty flavor, very well balanced in every respect. Very slight bitterness accompanies the malt. Spice and fruit are definitely present. Pretty tasty; however, definitely doesnt deserve such a high rating here on Ratebeer...

On tap @Murphy's. Rich malty aroma. Tan head with medium bubbles. Good lacing. Dark red brown color. Excellent malty flavor with interesting spice notes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2014 Fresh 2013 Jubelale from the bottle. Poured a deep, dark red color with a thick tan head. Carbonation was medium-high, with nice lacing on the glass. Aroma definitely is malt-forward with the essence of plum/date fruits and caramel. The higher carbonation also gave the aroma a bit of a CO2 "bite". Nice medium bodied mouthfeel and finished with a slight astrigentness from the dark malts & bitterness from the hops. Overall, a very nice fall/winter ale from Deschutes!

Poured fresh 2014 from bottle to glass. Dark reddish brown hue with creamy brown head that settled. Aroma is toffee, molasses, dates, caramel, cereal, burnt sugar. Mouthfeel is great with a medium body and crisp carbonation. Taste is sweet followed by a nice lightly roasted astringent following and somewhat savory finish. Overall this is a great beer again this year.
Chocolate malt, astringent, full body, sticky, thick feel, soft carbonation, heavy cloying sweetness, dark brown color, burnt almost stout flavor. Not one of my favorites.

Aroma is malty with hints of fruit sweetness. Pours a dark ruby-amber with an off-white collar and nice ringed lacing. The taste is malt forward with hints of caramel, nuts, bread and perhaps some dark fruit. Slightly sweet but has a nicely balanced hop finish. Missed the chicory.?? Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation medium. Overall, while enjoyable, it could have been bolder in flavor.
Pours a ruby haze with a tan head. Aroma is malt forward, slight caramel with some dough. Taste is notably bread-forward, with a spicy hop background. Some coffee notes in the finish.

Reddish brown in color... Malty, spiced aroma... Flavor is malty and sweet, spices, caramel with nutty and slightly bitter finish... Solid

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. This is a nice strong brew for winter time with just enough spicing to notice.

12 oz bottle from Evergreen Discount Liquors. Deep dark brown with red hues and a nice tan head. Aroma and flavor dark malts, earth, spices, dark fruit and light roast. Enjoying this during the first snow of the year.

Bottle from Davidsons Liquors. Pours coca-cola brown with a thin khaki head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. Massive raisin and licorice in the nose. Bold and flavorful of the tongue with a hint of sweetness. Has a touch of bitterness on the finish to clean things up. Hard to go wrong with this brewery.

T start, this is one of the best brown ales I have had. The aroma is a perfect balance of hops and malt to would expect from the style. The taste matches the smell. Well balanced slightly spicy hops followed by earthy malt flavor. Mouthfeel is medium yet complex.
Mahogany pour with a brown head. Aroma is toasted malt, nutty. Taste is nutty, toasted malt, and it has a dry finish. OK lacing.
Pours a clear garnet/amber with a full pale orange head. Aroma is roasted malt and spices. Nice sweet roasted malt taste, buttery with a medium hop bitterness. Good effort.

Dark amber pour, mostly clear. Nice persistent tan foam. Aroma is slight. Body is heavier than I expected, but good. Flavor is a good blend of bitter, malty, and hoppy. Carmel flavor in the aftertaste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013 bottle- possibly better then 2012. Sweet dark fruit, malt, caramel, burnt sugar, clove aromas. Pours a deep red with a caramel colored head with excellent lacing. Medium bodied with a toffee, caramel, earth, fruit and hints of roast and chocolate. I love this years winter warmer a great evening beer!

Bb date: 03/18/13 Sweet candied malt, spice, mild hops for a good balance. Creamy lactose with a piney hops well balanced on the finish. I know they put a bb date on the label so they can sell their next seasonal... Its still a good beer.... The spices married well..

When poured, this beers gorgeous cloudy reddish brown color is immediately apparent and the medium tan head that fades quickly is quick to follow. The aroma blends roasted malts, clove, and caramel malts, and the taste is very indulgent with its slight umami, touch of sweetness, and mild sourness. The palate combines a full body, slick texture, soft carbonation, and a long malty finish.

Bottle [12oz] shared with HogTownHarry, jercraigs & mabel -- c/o j&m. Pours a deep orange-amber with a small diminishing frothy beige head. Aroma of spice and malt, thats all I get. Flavour of spice and malt along with some leafy hops. Average bodied. It was fine, thats it.
Draft: Poured a copper orange with a tan off white head. Aroma is fruity with some spice. Taste is sweet with fruit and nice spice tongue feel.

2013-05-24. Mahogany red brown body, small beige head looks nice. 3++  Pleasant Aroma, modest malt, dark fruit, dusty malt, muted spice. Flavour is similar, dryish malt, dark fruit, light spice. Average bodied palate, modest carbonation. Just okay. Bottle via trade with Ferris"Deschutes dey score!"

12oz  bottle shared by jercraigs & mabel with me and blankboy.  Slightly hazy amber.  Taste and aroma are anise roast, dry floral bitterness, eehhhh.  Light body and carbonation, dry earthy bitter medium finish.  Whatever.  Shut up - am drunk.
Bottle.  Pours a reddish brown color with off-white head.  Caramel, malty, slight alcohol aromas.  Caramel, malty, spice flavors.  Tastes like a malty barleywine. Not my favorite Deschutes offering.
An amber brown beer with an average frothy white head. Aroma is malty with notes of caramel and dried fruits. Flavor is also malty and caramel, hoppy, slightly roasted. Dry finish. Good beer
A nice beer but it didnt taste like an ale. It was overly malty for an ale but still a nice beer.
Malty toffee aroma. Deep murky copper color. Pretty full bodied. Has a slight berry bitterness to it which is rounded off by the malts - finishing with the alcohol coming through.

smells of sweet fruit and malts with some brown sugar it pours an extremly dark brown with nice root beer colored head color is a deep red when held up to light mmmm tastes like toffee, malts caramel with a wee bitter after taste coated in brown sugar all around sharp smooth beer

Pours a clear, dark, amber color with a caramelcolored head that has an orangish hue. Aromas are comprised of an earthiness and brown sugar. Creamy, smooth mouthfeel. Toasty, butterscotch, and toffee flavor with a piney bitterness at the finish. Average to slightly above average.
On tap at Minneapolis Town Hall. 2012 vintage. Dark pour, complex flavor profile - recommended.

Special 25th Anniversary bottle, in a tulip glass.  Pours a stout-black colour with a fingers worth of tan head, steadily receding.  Big hops on the nose; grapefruit zest and pine, faint sweetness.  Flavour hits you again right away with the hops, fading quickly to coffee, bitterness and sweetness fairly balanced, though perhaps leaning towards dry rather than malty.  Not what I was actually looking for in a winter ale (I generally expect them to be sweet and malty,) but certainly not unwanted.  Quite well done, worth having again, though perhaps when Im in the mood for hops.
On tap.  Comes dark amber with a small beige head.  Aroma of malt, fruit, caramel, and pine.  Taste is malt, dark fruits, spice, caramel, pine, grass, and alcohol.  A lot going on here.  Nice.
Beautiful Olde English Ale.  Read the product description and the other reviews... they nailed it.  Nuff said.
Pours a very deep amber with a medium creamy off white head that laced.  Aroma of caramel, dark fruits, nuts and citrusy notes.  Flavor of pine, grapefruit, caramel, dark fruits.
Dark amber colour with a good foamy head. Stout like taste, with aftertaste of a strong dark chocolate.  Smooth mouth feel. (K)
On draft at Ojai Beverage Company. Dark amber pour with just a thin white head. Hop forward almost a Barleywine feel, but not much sweetness to balance.

Pours dark brown with a brown head.  Nose is caramel malts, spice you would find from rye, some brown sugar and banana.  Taste is sweet with a great bitter balance.  Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy, alcohol burns the pallet a little.  The body is heavy and the finish is long.

Amber-brown with a thick, resilient head. Caramel, chocolate syrup, raisin, blackcurrant, roasted malt, and a touch of grass at the end. Bitter, malty, medium- to light-bodied, and an abrupt finish.

Good session beer.

Pint at Darby's. Airy white cap on clear, reddish dark brown body. Cap reduces to bubbly, nerd zits. Aroma is all about roasted nuts, and molasses, caramel. Tastes like the glass just tea bagged my tastebuds. Nice nuts. Prunes, more molasses, caramel, and white chocolate with a bit o' coffee. So creamy! Great lacing on glass too. Gentle bitterness that leaves a late, and lasting, dry finish. 

Pretty sure Chef's chocolate salty balls might taste similar to this. And I'd gobble them up at every chance he gave me.

Very nice ale here. Pours what initially appears light brown but settles with an amber-copper essence; aroma is pleasantly malty with come bitter notes; well balanced ale which has more depth than expected, nice wintry brew.

Poured into my Deschutes snifter.  Deep, dark brown color with a light beige head.  Aroma is sweet and malty with cinnamon and spices as well as raisins and dark fruit.  Flavor matches the aroma well with a lot of dark fruit notes, some roastiness, and some spice.  Nice balance of the flavors; not overwhelmed by the spices like some winter beers.  Medium bodied with a long finish.  Overall a very nice winter ale.

6-pack from Whole Foods. At first, I dont think I cared all that much for this beer. After allowing things to warm up during the first half of the AFC championship I have a clearer idea of why people love it so much. The hop profile is quite prominent and initially turned me off as the complexities of the malt were less apparent at cooler temperatures. Big wafts of caramel are present now along with some peppery accents and a dash of alcoholic heat. The hops now make a lot more sense as anything more subtle would simply be lost in the shuffle.

Rich ruby tinted light brown coloured body with a dense, five centimetre tall tan head that leaves a nice lace - this is exactly what a winter beer should look like. Aroma of toasted malt, raisins, figs, plums, alcohol and a hint of pine. Light to Medium-bodied; Assertive roasty flavours with good fig, pit fruit and apple sweetness, a hint of light spice on the finish and some good assertive nuts and earthiness akin to English beers. Aftertaste relatively complex with some alcohol, coffee, nuts and toasted malt all noticeable. Overall, a very good beer, strong and pungent but not bridging the gap of spiced beer - definitely good to sample and a holiday staple without being too pungent. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Liqour Collection in Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii on 10-December-2012 for US$2.25 sampled at home on the Eastern Shore of Virginia on 18-January-2013.

Pours a dark ruby brown with a finger of off white head that dissipates fairly quickly to a film.  Leaves some nice lacing on snifter.  Can smell caramel and fig on the nose with a hint of apple and some spicing.  More of a roasty flavor than expected along with some nutmeg and slight sweet fruit taste.  A roasty tasting bitter that borders on astringent.  Not too bad a beer but I enjoyed the nose more than the taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle.  Pours a reddish brown with a two-finger off-white head and nice lacing.  The aroma is mostly malty with some hops.  Taste is malty with brown sugar, maple syrup, and coffee.  Very good.

Bottle to wine glass.  Pours hazy brown with red hues and a foamy tan head.  Aroma is malty with caramel, nutmeg, and raisin.  Taste is malt with the hops coming through at the end.  Slight sweetness.  Bitterness is more roasted than piney or grassy.  It clings to the tongue the more you drink and became somewhat unpleasant to my taste.  Mouthfeel is a little slick and dry.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pint on tap.  Really interesting spin on the style.  Drawn from a nitro-tap, it looks spectaular, walnut-black & opaque with a tan collar.  All the different hops create a great bouquet absent from other beers of the style.  Taste is wonderful, its a great marriage of traditional style and artisan craftsmanship, in my opinion.  Full-bodied beer with medium aftertaste and linger.

Its definitely a good beer- the winter spices are subtle and it has a nice hoppiness-, but the bitterness that follows sticks around way too long. Its not even a hoppy bitter, its like squirting grapefruit juice on coffee beans and eating it... which I did growing up, I was a dumb kid. Good beer, though. Just not great.
12oz bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown with red hues. Aroma of dried cherries, fig, caramel, raisin. Flavor is grain, dried fruit, brown sugar, caramel, pine.

Bottle. Pours a deep amner-brown with a medium, off-white head (excellent retention and mad lacing). Nose is deep roasted malts, maple syrup, caramel , butterscotch and (for lack of a better word) Christmas. Mouth is porter-esque with dark roasted malts and coffe notes up front, some cocoa, caramel, maple and toffee on the back end. Pleasantly lingering, bitter finish. Good stuff. Welcome to Chicago, Deschutes! And a belated Merry Christmas.

Chestnut-to-mahogany color, big head of mixed-form density. Fennel, tobacco, chocolate, toast aroma. Great label on the 25th anniversary bottle. Richer aroma as it warms. A little alcohol noted. Bitterness in the finish. Reasonably good but I didnt enjoy it enough to like a whole bottle. Bottle.
Clear dark amber pour with thick off white head. Aroma of malts, caramel, bread and yeast. Taste of malts, caramel, toffee, slightly nutty and a mild hop bitterness that lingered. Very good beer.

Bottle from trade with michaelinwa.  Pours a very dark amber color with a nice frothy head that lingers a bit.  Aromas are caramel, toffee, vanilla, fruit cake, and brown sugar.  Taste is slightly sweet, lots of caramel, toffee and fruit cake.  Finish is a bit dry and abrupt.  Medium body and somewhat chewy mouthfeel.  A pretty solid malty and sweet winter ale.

Pours a bright ruby tinted mahognay brown with a thick yellow coloured head. A ton of frothy whipped lacing coasts the glass. The nose is of heavy toffee and caramel malts, rye and bready notes, a hint of citrus malts with a light splash of vanilla. Smooth and malt forward with big caramel and biscuity bread malts, heavy toffee and sweet brown sugar notes.  A bit of a citrus hop and light resinous flavours. Not well balanced, but a good malty heavy ale with a mild earthen note. Overall, quite good.

Pours nice. Tastes great but the aroma felt muted for some reason. Nice robust hop profile but is a still definitely a winter brown ale. Yum

On tap at the Foundry: pours dark clear amber, thin khaki ring. Nutmeg, caramel malts, smoked wood and bread, dark fruit on the nose. Roasted malts, caramel malt sweetness, nutmeg and Xmas spices with a reasonable mid body. Sessionable Xmas beer

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep dark red with small tan head.  Aroma is pronounced caramel malt.  Big malty flavor with some bitterness to match.  Quite good.

Bottle to Christmas glass at mother in law's place. Citrus (grapefruit) and caramel. Dark red/brown with khaki head, good retention. Nice Christmas spice. Balanced moderate sweetness with lightly bitter finish. Medium body.  Short finish. Solid, balanced, pleasant.

Brown pour with medium tan head. Hoppy grapefruit nose with a background of caramel malt sweetness.  Flavor matches the smell. Really balanced dry finish.

Pours very rich with an amber or even red color. Taste is malty, with hints of chocolate and fruit. Flavor also quite hoppy but a good combo. overall a good choice

25th anniversary bottle.  It poured a dark brown color with a small tan head. The aroma was big caramel and malts, with some toffee as well. The taste was of toffee and malt with some dark fruit. Very nice.

Type:  12-oz. bottle

Poured a mahogany color with 2-3 fingers of frothy off-white head. Well-layered, thick and sticky lacing on the sides. Pretty good retention all the way down.

Smelled heavy malts right from the get-go. Also got caramel, toffee, dark fruits, blueberry, rye and iced tea with a touch of hops. 

First thing I noticed in the taste was how carbonated it was. Once that was done, got some fruits - dark apple, dates, figs, prune - and a bit of a buttery finish. 

Medium body. Sticky texture. Lively (good) carbonation. Long, smooth finish.

This beer wore down on me as it went along and I was really digging it by the end. Just a nice winter warmer.
On draught at San Benito. Pours reddish brown with a light brown head. Aroma of malt and deep fruit follows through on the flavor. Slight bitter finish.
Malty toffee aroma.  Deep murky copper color.  Pretty full bodied.  Has a slight berry bitterness to it which is rounded off by the malts - finishing with the alcohol coming through.
On tap. Amber to red with a creamy off white top. Scent is caramel and earth. Taste is the same.
Very malty and sweet. Quite bitter, both hoppy and chocolatey. Full bodied and delicious.

Aroma sumamente agradable. Notas frutales muy complejas, malta y ligeramente caramelo. Se percibe cierto Lupulo aromatico.

Cerveza color oscuro con notas rubi a contra luz. Cuerpo medio, cabeza de eapuma abundante y de buena retención. 

En boca se percibe efervesencia, amargor y sequedad.

Al paladar, cerveza con imponente amargor, sequedad en garganta, sabor frutal agradable. Final medio con notable sensación alcoholica.

En general, muy buena cerveza de temporada con aroma excelente, muy buena apariencia y equilibrio entre el amargor y sabores frutales.
Deep mahogany, tan head.  Cocco, nutmeg, and  a hint of licorice on the nose.  Tongue is sweet.  Dark carmelized malt with spruce in the middle.  FInish is still sweet, but dried with piney hops.

Pours a brown colour with big tan head lacing the glass really well. Aromas of sweet caramel, dried fruit, some malty nuttiness. Flavours of roasted malts, caramel, dry/burnt/bitter finish. An average beer.
Decent brew. Rich malt, almost spicy at times with the robust yeast. Not bad.
12 ounce bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours reddish brown with a medium tan head.   Nose and flavor are malt, spice, alcohol, dark fruit, caramel.  Some bitter hops.  Medium mouthfeel.  Just ok.

Aroma brings scents of wet hops, candied sugar, and yeast. Deep ruby/crimson in color with a two finger sized foam head. Slightly creamy caramel, oak and bourbon upfront with an assertive bitterness on the finish. Some toasty, toffee, resin and oat notes lingering further on the finish. Overall, this is a very well done and unique ale with a strong alcohol warmth. Id give this an A rating.
Aroma and taste are pretty well matched, toasted malty caramel with delicious underlying bitterness. Syrupy in body, in a good way.

Bottle - Malty with some alcohol, raisins and spice.  Clear dark amber with a rich off white head that lingers.  Malts, sweet dark fruits, bitterness from hops and caramel.  There is a bit of kick at the end, but all in all nothing very special.  I have high expectations from Deschutes and was a little underwhelmed.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2012 Pours a clear red color with a huge brown head that forms into a nice top that lasts the beer and leaves some sticky lacing. Aroma is a bit fruity, malty nuttiness and has some sweet caramel.  Taste is cereal, nuts and caramel up front and then a medium dry finish and a steady but abrubt bitterness that sticks around and kind of kills this beer.  Has a kind of creamy mouthfeel as well, interesting beer overall.

Bottle poured into schooner. Deep red color, low carbonation, little head that goes quickly with heavy lacing. Smells of malt, caramel. Steady light bitter balances big malt, caramel with fruity background.

12oz bottle, Best by 03/13/13 from Olive Tree Market in OB. Clear orangeish brown with a 1 1/2 finger  medium dark beige head, good retention. Fruity English ale yeast up front in the aroma with some toasted malt nuttiness and a bit of sweet caramel. A bit like fruit cake, really.  Flavor is much the same, seems a little more toasty and caramelly, not all that sweet, and the fruity ale yeast is still present, but not as strong.  The finish is semi-dry with bitterness peaking at a 3-4. Low creamy carbonation with a medium body. Not my favorite style, but this is done well and tasty for an ESA.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Hazy, amber-brown pour with a frothy, tan head.  The aroma has caramel and bread, but there is also a decent amount of herbal hops plus a touch of pine.  It has a medium body with a slightly sticky texture and average carbonation.  The taste is more bitter than I would expect, but still nice.

Slight acidic and burnt coffee flavor. Bitterness is there, but not from the hops. Strong malt backbone.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2014 2014: Fruity aroma: Cherry, citrus. Some dark fruity malt, and spice. Similar fruity flavor, with sweetness nd a little tartness. A lot more spice in the flavor.

2012: Raisin/Cherry aroma. Similar fruity flavor -- Plus some citrus, and a lot of spiciness. A little alcohol flavor. Substantial bitterness; but its smooth. All brought together pretty well with a sweetish malt character.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy brown color with a small off white head.  The aroma is sweet caramel malts, dark fruits, spices and even a hint of alcohol.  The flavor is lightly toasted malt, caramel, earthy, mild spices with some dark fruits.  Decent.

Pours deep red/brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma is sweet caramel, stone fruit, malt, ab bit of earth, wood.  Taste is sweet malt, nicely balanced with some bitter hops. Nice mouth feel, over all very nice.

pours dark amaretto brown, decent foamy head, ringed retention, sticky lacing, some slow streams. Caramel malts on the nose. Drinks with a thick creaminess up front, quickly turning caramel hoppy bitter balanced by 4/10-sweetness, burnt roast, cocoa, finishing long lingering dry hopped bitter. Medium complexity, med-high depth, good carry, okay transitions, okay drinkability. The heavy bitterness is taxing on the palate.

Deep copper, clear, fluffy tan head.  Aroma of toffee, toasty malt, spicy hops.  Flavor is deeply malty with caramel, some dark fruit and a toasty quality.  Some lingering bitterness.  Full bodied winter warmer.  Pleasant.
Out of the bottle, a nice fluffy head on a dark pour.  Too much malt for me, and the hops added too make it pretty bitter.  I like the caramel but not one of my favorite holiday brews.
Love this beer.  Palate is very creamy.  Great head that hangs around for quite a while.  Fantastic malty flavor.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2012 Taster on tap at Hops in New West. A limited impression that Ill have to explore more fully next visit, but its quite malty, with substantial hops. A full glass next visit for sure.
Okay! Here we are, back at Hops in New West, for a full snifter of the good stuff. Color is a very dark ruby; black for all intents. Its a maxi-pour, so not much reading on head. The flavour is lovely. Its sweet and rich, and just a bit bitter. Nice one!

Bottle to taster
Mango, sage, pine, alcohol. Clear reddish amber with a thin tan head. Taste is bitter coffee and burnt malts.

Tap at Deschutes Brewery & Public House, Portland - 07/11/12.
Menu notes that this beer was brewed in the Portland brewing facility.
Hazy dark amber with a thin off white head that clears to the edge and forms a pond.
Nose is dark fruits, spice, touch of wood, light cherry notes.
Taste follows, spice, dark fruits, a little booze, malt, wood.
Full bodied with soft carbonation leading to a fruity boozey finish.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle. Dark fruit, roasted malts and bitter chocolate. Caramel and candied sweetness in the background. Light pine finish. Tasty.
Deep copper brown with creamy off-white head.  Malty rich and full bodied with good hop balance.

Pours opaque brown with a half finger of tan head. Settles quickly with some lacing. Smells malty, caramel, dough, mild spice and fruity tones. Flavor is slightly hoppy up front with mild coffee and roasted malt tones. Then turns nutty with caramel and malty notes. Very mild sour grape/grapefruit/stone fruit hints that become more noticeable as it warms. Medium carbonation and medium body. Slightly oily and astringent finish. A good seasonal.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2013 This beer is really nice. Dark reddish brown appearance. Fresh floral and slice aroma. Complex taste. Caramel and pine flavor with a pleasant,strong bitter aftertaste.

Also, the Deschutes Jubelale chili recipe is worth it.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2013 (bottle)  Pours a dark red color with a large tan head that holds its form.  Gets the five.  Aroma is reminiscent of gingerbread, stewed plums, with light pine and some citrus that adds an element of freshness to the overall scent, but subdues the malt in the process.  Flavor holds some candied orange, light grapefruit (towards the finish), cocoa, caramel, toasted biscuit, and some dark fruit in the finish. After this hit of dark fruit follows a substantial pithy bitterness that lingers for quite some time.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is a touch spritzy.  Overall this is not a bad beer, but I think Id like it a little better with some age on it, as the hops seemed to dominate proceedings here.
2013 re-rate:  This batch is drinking really well so I had to bump the score.

Murky brown with foamy off-white head.  Fragrant aroma of dark fruit and Christmas spice.  Not as sweet and hoppier than I expected.  Rich roasted malts, almost stout like.  Also, english malt, dark chocolate, dark fruit and a generous amout of grassy bittering hops. Rather unique - pretty good but I dont love it.

Mahogany colored pour with a dense khaki colored head. Burnt sugar and toffee notes with a subtle spiciness, lots of dark fruit, and some toasted bread. Light herbal quality and a bit of yeast. The flavor is lightly bitter, but also quite sweet. Tons of toffee, some caramel, toasted bread, and dark fruits. A hint of yeast, light herbal hops, and a very light woodiness.
Aroma is malty and mildly vinous, somewhere between and old ale and barley wine.  The flavor is malts, definitely sweet, along with fruit, slight sour notes and an astringent/tart finish.
This was great. Strong sweet bubblegum aroma and sweet flavour, more like a Belgian style to me than English, but tasty nonetheless.

Bottle.  Pours a dark ruby color with a tan head.  Subtle aroma of toasted malt, toffee and baking spices.  Big malty flavor, with nutmeg and other various spices present.  Balanced with a pleasant, bitter finish.  Well carbonated with a dry texture.  Medium bodied.  All of the components jell very well together.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2013 On draught at Seaside Brewing Company 11/10/12. 2012 vintage. A pleasant nutty taste with a slight hop presence. From bottle 9/23/13. 2013 vintage. Dark brown color with golden tan head. Sweet dark malt aroma with nut and molasses notes. Taste is also sweet roasted malt, nuts, grassy hops, and hints of plum and toasted caramel. Finishes with a roasted nut and light hop bitter aftertaste.

Kinda red to dark copper with a decent head and good lacing.

Somewhat malty with almost and English Mild type aroma, but with plenty of hops as well and some notable wintry beerly notes.

Flavor is a bit again on the English mild side, though bolder and with a spicier than youd expect for a mild. Theres lots of grains and malts, along with some fruity notes and plenty of hops. Its actually a bit spicy, but apparently more for the amount of hops character Id expect in a winter warmer.

The body is well carbonated and medium, nice and on par for the style

Overall Id say that Deschutes has once again made a delicious beer and for the most part pegged it for the style.

I sure love Winter Seasonals.  This pours dark brown with a head that continues to kling to the sides.  Some spices are detectable with a strong pour, but soon give way to a more toffee like nose.  Again some spices like nutmeg up front, soon to be taken over by strong full malt flavors and a good balance of hop bitterness in the background.  Finishes clean with some dryness.
Medium brown color with a light head. Great balance of hops and malt and very drinkable.
2012 edition.  Really cool label art, as in most years.  Dark reddish brown pour with a cream colored head.  A nice hoppy bitterness along with a good mix of malt and spices.  Very good and tasty.

Beer glass at boombozz, gilbert, az. Aroma- very clean, barley smell  appearance- very inviting. Golden orange.  Taste- very smooth. Caramel butter flavor Almost a session beer. Palate- very clean. No aftertaste. Light cinnamon notes. Overall- much smoother than expected. Could drink this all night. Score is lower just because it feels like a session beer. But best session beer ever!

Appearance was clear reddish deep amber with lasting tannish creamy  1 finger head, rings of lacing. Aromas are sweet caramel, chocolate, rye amber  roasted malts, toffee, deep floral fruits of cherry & fig,hints of tangy alcohol. Taste are rich sweet  caramel, chocolate, rye malts backbone with piney  sticky resinous english bite. Palate was soft fizzy CO2 with meduim body, then lasting dryish bitter hoppy slick finish. Goooood  english strong...

Jubelale, after freezing it for a few minutes to get it cool - Pours amber with good head and a very even coat of lacing.  LOVE the aroma - terrific blend of caramel, spice, molasses, and toasty malts; maybe even a hint of fruit.  Smells unlike any beer Ive had before.  Taste - caramel, toasty malts, nuttiness, dash of sweetness, and a hop kick at the end.  Man this is good.

Pours a brown color with a translucent maroon hue.  Aroma is red-dark fruits and carmelized sugar.  Flavor has a  jam-cranberryish flavor up front and then gives way to a nice bitter toasted malt finish.  Unique   nice beer and enjoying it   makes me wonder if this is a belgian dubbel recipe with an english yeast used instead

Pint at the tap house in Portland. Of the 6 beers I tasted, this one was my favorite. Jubelale had a handful of flavors that played out nicely together, including figs, cinnamon, roasted barley, and a bitterness thats typical of English ales, but comes in as a supporting role this time. Jubelales bitterness set it apart from traditional and commonplace holiday spice beers.

Pours clear brown / burgundy with a large tan soapy head.  The aroma has dark toffee, caramel, heavy maltiness, lots of toast, molasses, and figs.  It is rich, but not too sweet.  Medium / full body with some frothy carbonation.  The flavor begins like a drier version of the aroma with dry rye bread and earthy / spicy hops and a hint of red berries.  The finish has more hops and earthiness.  Nice winter warmer.

Poured a dark copper/red color with off white head. the aroma of sweet malts, hops and spices and possibly dark fruits. The flavor was very good, my first winter beer this year. 
 Taste is rather complex for a Christmas beer. Begins slightly bitter with a roasted nutty flavor which leads to sweeter caramel notes and then finishes with a bit of hop bitterness, then a light xmas Spice. Very enjoyable offering, This will be one of my sought after brews every year. Too bad I live in Ohio.
Great winter ale! Full flavored, just the right blend of festive hops and deliciousness

Pours a dark copper with a foamy two finger tan head that lingers.  Aroma is of caramel, ripe fruits, raisins, some earthy hops, toffee, and some cinnamon.  Taste is of caramel malts, toasted bread, dark fruits, raisins, some earthy pine and citrus, toffee/bread pudding, and some spices including cinnamon and maybe some nutmeg.  Has a medium-full body with a creamy, buttery mouthfeel and a semi dry, semi bitter finish.  overall, a very tasty and complex winter seasonal.

I find this one to be of fine fettle, starting on the tip of the tongue with aggresive hints of a snappy cinnamon, quickly transitioning to a creamy buttery sip of awesome maltyness that flows across the tongue initially sweet then metamophisizing into an edgy bitter essence of nuts, and the desire to have another.
my fav beer of witer, carmel with buttery mouth feel, pretty dark pour with small beige head.

In the glass it has a nice amber color with a medium head. The aroma has sweet malts, caramel and is a little roasty. Taste has some sweet caramel malts and cinnamon. There is some roasted malts and a mild hop bitternes that balances the beer very well. Tasty.

Incredible old style English ale, great aroma and full malt flavor. Very strong hops influence in this one so it can be quite bitter. So if bitter ale, rich in hops is not your thing then this ale is not for you. Well worth trying and great with cheese dishes.

bottle. pours deep amber, full slight tan head.  nose is warm malt, a little roasty, and slightly astringent.  mouth is full amber malt, deep roast to match, with a hop bitter at the finish.  overall good winter, warming.
1.5 finger head, creamy, dark amber almost black color, off white head, caramel aroma, medium body, malty flavor.

Bought this beer in the bottle from Total Wine in Henderson, NV. Robust malt body with a lingering bitter aftertaste. A little too bitter for my liking.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours auburn, with an off white head. Aroma is caramel, banana, dark fruit, and earthy notes. Flavor is roasty malt with a good bit of booziness, spices, earth and coffee notes, with bitter finish.

This ale poured a cloudy dark amber, quickly dissipating, tan coloured head. Scents include very ripe fruit, banana, caramel and a little spice. First sip was quite hoppy with flavours of citus hops, ripe fruit, light smoke and roasted malt. Finish is bitter with ripe fruit and grassy hops flavours lingering.

Pour is a dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is big caramel and earthy malts, maybe some toffee in there as well.  Flavor is toffee, a big earthy malt with some dark fruit. I really dont get the hoppy fruit some others have gotten.  Still this is a very tasty winter warmer.  This would be a great beer by the fire.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2013 Tasted new 2012 vintage from 12oz brown bottle into tulip. It poured a beautiful clear dark reddish-brown color with lasting beige foam and lace. Nice aromas: bread, toast, coffee with cream, fragrant citrusy and earthy hops,  faint ale yeast esters. Classic Big-Brown-English-Ale flavors too: strong malt sweetness balanced by tangy hops bitterness, caramel, toffee. Light-medium body and moderate carbonation, just a hint of acidic tartness. Smooth and lasting fruity, bittersweet aftertaste. Great beer.
UPDATE 11/5/2013: Tasted this seasonal release again this year. This time more bitterness but less hoppy flavours and aromas than I remember. Nice toasty winter warmer, cool combination of Porter and IPA traits.
September 15, 2012 on tap at the Autumn Brew Review in Minneapolis.  Dark brown pour with no head.  Malt, sweet, hoppy and spice in aroma and taste.  2012 vintage.
Had this at the 2012 Autumn Brew Review. Had some nice subtle caramel notes and taste.

This came across as a typical winter brew. Upfront malty and grainy aroma. Chocolate and molasses appearance with a thick foamy head that looked like too much bubble bath. The roasted malt had a stronger alcohol tint than expected on the tongue. You could definitely distinguish the English-influenced characteristics. Good but far from perfect.
Twilight is a seasonal beer that uses the same UPC   Nice flavor that fits well with warm weather.
The bottle artwork is actually quite pretty at times. Sweet body with caramel notes and warm flavors.

down fairly slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of rich sweet caramel malts with some dark fruits, nutmeg, clove, and other spices, with some roastiness and molasses.

T - Starts off with some sweet caramel malts with some raisin and other dark fruits with a bit of cinnamon, clove, and other spices. Through the middle, some roasted malts start to come through alongside some bitter hop flavor molasses, and a touch of fruityness. The finish is a mix of sweet caramel malts with some caramelized sugars, dark fruit, some yeast character, and some more hop bitterness, cinnamon, clove, and nutmeg.

M - Medium-plus bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet and dry finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nicely balanced. The spices are at the right level and there is more than enough other flavor to balance.

355 ml bottle @ Higgins, Portland. BBE 15.+5.2012.
Pours dark red-brown color with small head. Aroma of plums, raisins, ripe fruits, caramel and mild hops. Flavor of caramel, ripe fruits, plums, raisins and some malts. Medium carbonation, bitter fruity sweet palate. Quite nice.
5426

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured clear dark brown color with medium light brown frothy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium to heavy toasted caramel malt, alcohol and hop aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted malt and hop flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a standout interesting brew.

Gotta love tht deep red color, a beautiful beer.  Slightly hazy though.  Smells sweet and you can smell a bit of alcohol. First taste is sweet but not overpowering. Slightly bitter and at the end you can taste the alcohol.  This year is not as good as the previous years brew, but still respectable. This beer is medium bodied and would go great with a steak i do believe.  Worth a buy and i will continue to travel 45 mins to buy it every year.
Pours a dark red brown with a cream head that settles to a ring. Aroma is toasted nutty malt, buttery,  and a hint of citrus. Taste is nutty, caramel, and a little pine. Creamy on the palate.
Pours a a dark brown color with a large tan head. Aroma of caramel malt and toffee. Taste is caramel, dark fruits and toffee. Medium bodied and creamy.

On tap at Churchhills. Deep  murky purple pour. Creamy beige head. Lacing stayed forever. Aromas of roasty chocolate, heavy malt. Taste was a balance mix of dark fruit, whiskey, black chery and dr pepper. Cool beer.

From notes. Pours a rich redish murky brown with a thick creamy tan head that leaves beautiful lacing. 
Nice sweet aroma, dark fruit, spices, cinnamon, clove, some dark roasted malt and sweet malt hold it all together.
Very similar to the nose, the flavor is malty with plenty of spice, mostly cinnamon with a little brown sugar.
Solid medium body with a charming medium-light carbonation that really compliments everything going on without getting in front of the flavors.
Tghis poured a semi murky darker red color with a beige head. Aroma was nutty, some dark fruits and a hint of chocolate too.  Flavor was of dates and figs, light toffee and some nuts. Ehh.

Dark red brown with a nice offwhite head that fades to leave a thick lacing. 
Sweet smell of malt with a fair amount of spices.  Just a hint of hops at the end. Taste starts off malty and sweet and finishes suprisingly hoppy.  Well balanced beer.

Pours a burnt orange to amber hue with a big, latte colored creamy head that wants to hold on.  Smells of spicy malts, clean caramel, dark fruits, smells terrific - couldnt get enough and ended up with a big blob of that creamy head on my nose.

This is not normally a style that gets much of my appreciation but this is great, lovely malts and that milky layer of head floats in to add to a near perfect mouthfeel, its like a milkshake without the milk, or the shake for that matter.

Just goes to show that you cant judge a book by its cover, a style of beer can vary greatly and I seem to have forgotten that, Id highly recommend this.

10 feb 2012, bottle. Dark brown/red, clear. Tart caramel, malty alcohol. Thin/med body and fizzy. Chocolate and grassy hops. Works pretty well. Some burnt notes. Nice for an all around med/heavy ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
(tap) (cask) clear dark amber, medium size brown head; aromas of roast, citrus; faint aroma, balanced mellow flavour, average

12 oz. bottle, the fourth I have consumed from a six-pack purchased two or three months ago. Aroma features plum, raspberry, cherry; carob, chocolate-covered raisins; chalk, dust, crayon, clay; and hints of lemon, white vinegar, and salt. Complex, intriguing, and entertaining smell. Pours a bright amber that glows almost red. The liquid is clear and effervescent. Moderate to large amount of thick, creamy, uneven, tan head. Produces nice, extensive lacing. Sharp and tart flavor. Malty taste with flavors of dark chocolate shavings and banana bread minus the banana (so, um, bread? Perhaps not my most meaningful beer descriptor). Id like the flavors to be a little more complex and varied, but they are quite good. Very dry, chalky finish and aftertaste. Medium body. Soft in the palate. Jubelale is a really nice, tasty, enjoyable beer. Well done, Deschutes!

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2012 Courtesy of 5000 via trade 
Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate grape, plum, chocolate, spice, and faint alcohol. It pours a hazy, bordering on cloudy, orangish-brown with some sediment and a small beige head. The flavor starts with chocolate and light plum. The finish has notes of raisin, grape, alcohol, and faint spice. Its medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation and a somewhat creamy mouthfeel.
Draft. Less spicey then most winter brews .......nice change up. Sweeter malt taste with less hop bitterness.  Fairly thin.

12oz bottle poured at wwbf asheville. dark copperish/ red color with off white head. the aroma of sweet malts, hops and spices possibly dried dark fruits. the flavor was very good one of the better winter beers i have had this year. the flavors of the sweetness that comes from the malt and from the reading above the caramel...very good beer.
Draft.  Pours copper with off-white head.  Smell is light hops, sweetness from malts and almost a ripe fruit quality.  Initially very malt forward; biscuity and caramel with some sweet ripe fruit.
Bottle from 09. Pours a dirty brown color with a tan head. Has a sweet malt smell to it. Has a caramel, malt and slight bitterness in the end. Overall not a bad beer Id drink it again

On tap at Aces. Pours a beautiful deep amber with a creamy foam head. Aroma of earthy hops and cinnamon like spice. Medium to light body with good carbonation. Taste of spice and some caramel but this is not a sweet beer. Bitterness and spice in the finish.

12oz bottle.  Brownish pour with short lasting head.  Nose is full of winter type spices.  So is the taste plus a mild hop kick.  Fairly thin.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

01.02.2011 - Houston, TX
Bottle

Finishing up a Christmas beer reserve. Full palate with a bite to the finish. A bit of sherry hint to it.

Pours a deep, dark brown with a thick tan head. Aromas of brown sugar, dates and cinnamon. Medium bodied with a strong caramel malt presence with flavours similar to the nose. Its pleasantly sweet and the carbonation is bang on. The hops emerge on the finish - just enough to take away from the sweet body. Very nice.

Bottle - pours deep ruby with a light creamy head and some lacing. Has a sweet malty aroma and a hop bitter finish that isnt overdone. I like it! One of the better holiday beers Ive had this season.
20oz pint at Shakespeares in Houston. Deep chestnut brown. Thin head, great body. A very good Old Ale or Winter Warmer style ale.
Light brown with little head. Aroma has hoppiness, toffee, spices. Quite light, tastes of grains with a bit of toffee. Hops and grain struggle to try and give any flavour but only barely make it.

Pours a deep, rich brown w/ nice khaki head, great-looking beer. Attractive aroma, brown sugar, raisins, cinnamon, spice. Good flavors, tasty, comes hoppier than expected but in check, warming, creamy, good mouthfeel, balanced.

I popped the lid and was greeted by Christmas in a bottle! "Jingle Bells, Jingle Bells..." Wow!!! I poured this into a pint glass and watched as the dark amber liquid blossomed with 2 fingers worth of a mocha colored head and amazing lacing. The aroma of holiday spices practically filled the whole room. One sip of this beer and I was sold; this was a solid brew. The beer had a wonderful taste like something akin to a beer version of hot cider only cold. The spices were abundant but not overbearing and the malt was perfectly balanced with the hops leaving a slightly bitter aftertaste.
I always look forward to the release of the Jubelale. Malty, warm, just the right amount of hops, but definitely a winter beer. Nicely balenced.

Bottled sample. Redish brown in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas are of pale malt, cooked sugar, and a touch of orchard fruit. Solid malt flavours dominate, along with notes of mellow caramel, earthy hops, and a very subtle hit of roast on the back end. Black peppery bitterness on the finish. Really well balanced, and surprisingly drinkable. Good stuff!

Bottle.  Ruby brown pour.  Pours with a 2 inch head that recedes to a half inch that lasts the ten or so minutes it takes to drink the beer.  Aroma is of roasted malts toffee and caramel.  Taste is a good balance of bitter hops and sweeter malts.  As beer warms the taste becomes sweeter, almost sugary.  Body is medium.  A nice winter beer.
From memory.  Pours a deep amber with a deep tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt and some spice.  Taste is nice caramel malt with a touch of nutty spices.  Some alchohol present.  Nice stuff.
I love Olde Ales and Strong Ales, but I see this more in the vein of a stout although there is a remnant of hops. Great dominant carmel malt

12 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy reddish amber color.  Foamy tan head, nice lacing.  Aroma is a malty caramel and toffee.  Flavor very hoppy, with a great thick malty backside.  Overall this is a great beer.

On tap at Dantes in the University of Washington district in Seattle. Poured into a pint glass. 
Appearance was dark amber to mahogany. There was a gentle lacing with very little head to speak of. As you drink, the lacing stays on the side of the glass (almost like a Christmas ornament). 
Aroma was spicy, with red fruits. It has a pretty sweet note to it.
Tasted almost like an abbey ale at first. Lots of character and no real surprises after the smell. Its warming and drinkable with heavy fruits (cherry) and minimal alcohol burn. Almost spicy. Very crisp and drinkable with a lot of carbonation. Im currently aging one so Im excited to see what it turns in to. There is a small bland aftertaste, but its not that bad.
Overall its a very drinkable, very festive beer. If its available and youre feeling in the mood, pick one up.
A fine "wintry" tasting brew. Nice and heavy, hearty. No doubt you could drink these all night.

12 oz bottle local grocery. Pours amber dark reddish. Half inch light tan heAd. Aroma is heavily bready. Good malt backbone with fruity flavors as well on the palate. Expecting a fuller body but its more on the medium side. Finish is dry that balances it off nicely. Bread aroma, sweet fruity taste and a dry finish to sum it up. Goes down nicely.

A pleasant fruity aroma foreshadows the sweet, well balanced, fruity taste. The finish leads into a grassy and sweet aftertaste. The color is ruby red and the beer has a tall head that dissipates into a rocky mess. The body is medium bodied and the beer has a decent amount of alcoholic warmth to it. This is a good beer that Id drink year round if I could.

Pours dark ruby red/brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is fruity with some caramel notes and perhaps a hint of citrus hops. Medium mouthfeel with moderate carbonation. Taste is rather complex. Begins slightly bitter with a roasted nutty flavor which leads to sweeter caramel notes and then finishes with a bit of hoppy bitterness. Very enjoyable offering, one of my favorite winter seasonal brews.
A very pleasant beer. Malty, rich, but yet easily drinkable- nice fruity finish. A pretty decent beer.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2015 re-rate 12/15......lowered more  from 3.8.   taste buds must be changing - too boozy and hoppy for me - the spices dont do flavor any good.  no need to drink more.  not sure this is my style.............................................  11/14  lowered from 4.0   complex beer with several things going on; not quite a 4 but solid............................................. oz bottle -mmmm!   Malty aroma plus dark fruit. amber/brown pour.  Nice palate/mouthfeel.  

Taste - several levels to it which is why I think I like this so much.  started sweet and slightly dry.  definite caramel/toffee up front.  slight hops in middle and ends dry - just a damn good beer!!

Pours a bright ruby red with thin white head. Aroma is full of caramel, biscuit, and I swear I can get some peanut butter creeping in.  Taste is very malty and fruity, but not without a bit of hops.   Really a nice beer!

Lots of carmel and hops.  Gives almost a rootbeer taste on the tongue, a bit herbal.  Lovely hops in the finish.  I really appreciate how they bring out the hops at the end like that.  Medium carbonation, with not much head but some lace on the sides of the glass.  Nice mahogany/tea color, fairly clear.  Overall, a very nice offering for the holidays!

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2011 12 oz bottle of the 2011 Jubelale- Poured into a sniffer....Very Earth and Fruity aroma, Hints of Apricot; Grass; Banana...Appearance is Ruby red with a 1 finger tan Head..Taste is Earthy and Clean with some very light hints of something citrus..The Roof of my mouth is really feeling this one..But could be the sampling of a few bottles tonight...Overall I would say drink more than 1 of these..I had my first few on warm days and i Didnt think much of it...But today at about 40deg. outside it was a new beer, I enjoyed it much more in the cold..Cant wait to find more of this brew.

Pours a dark, mahogany brown with a moderate, tan head.  Nose is bubble gum and banana.  Flavor is slightly roasted flavors and a slight sweetness, with perhaps a touch of banana and hops notable on the finish.  A nice beer that is very drinkable but not spectacular.

A good ale.  Lots of malt and caramel, and a good hop kick as well.  Aroma is pretty standard ale aroma, I was expecting a little more festive aroma from this one.  Palate is basic strong ale, lots of lingering malts, a slightly creamy mouthfeel, and a long hop finish.  A very enjoyable beer.

12oz bottle. Rating #668. Great looking beer, I love these dark ruby red colors of some of these winter beers. Nice looking head, kind of chocolate milk like, but on the lighter side. Rich caramel and light spice aroma, almost a little toast as well. Dark rich light roasted flavor with a faint hint of spice. Real tasty beer. (1991)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
not really my style of beer, but this one is really good.  porter-like smell.  big interesting palate and taste.  Nice bitter finish.  Clean.  I had this with some indian food and it was a very rich and rewarding experience.  I had one of their Hop Trip pale ales earlier and this one is much more impressive.

Nice Job.

Bottle.  Dark ruby pour with tan head and good lacing.  Aroma is brown sugar, dark fruits, spice, and some hops.  Quite bitter, lots of hoppy bitterness, but ultimately this is caramel and other malty flavors.  Sticky, medium (if not slightly thin) body.  A great winter beer.
one of the best "holiday" beers Ive had...great reddish color, with a slightly malty taste...

Sampled at an esbls tasting.  From Shep.  Clear and dark brown.  A nice light tan head.  I smell brown sugar but it is not big.  A big malt start has rye and bitter hops.  Chocolate and coffee.  This was tasty and interesting.

Tastes of coffee grounds and dark malt.  Underlying sweetness balanced by a sharp bitterness.  Similar to a porter without as much heavy feeling or bite on the back end.  Not horrible but I am not much of a fan.

Its a nice looking beer with a deep burgundy color and a foamy head that dissipates quickly.  Not much of a nose to it, but that may just be me.  It has a satisfying creamy, full-bodied texture.  While it has a nice warming feel to it, it is not the most flavorful beer Ive had.  Hints of raisin and malt, but for the most part theres not much to it.  Good, but not great.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter.  Pours a dark red clear color.  Off white head.  Aromas of carmel and malt.  Sweet malts dominate throughout finishing with a sweet bourbon like taste.  The underlying warming alcohol is detectable which surprises me that this is only 6.7%.
12 oz. Bottle: Aroma of malt and caramel. Full and complex taste and finish. A decent ale.

Poured into my deschutes Tulip glass. Dark color, nice head and lacing. Aroma is malty, but not very proliferate. Flavor is good though. Good bitterness and malt balance . Overall a decent winter warmer, though I believe there is better out there. Finishes dry.

Pours dark reddish almost brown with off white head, aroma has notes of toffee, some earthy notes, touch of minerals in there as well, with a touch of grass.  Taste is lots of sweet toffee, slight hint of cocoa, lots of spice, hints of grass, biscuit, pine, touch of molasses, finishes bitter and dry.  Nice brew, very rich but tasty!

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 Pours a dark brown, with tons of thick head that lasts, and sticks to the side of the glass--a good sign. Wonderful aroma from this one, a mix of roasted malt and hops--very nice. Taste is surprisingly complex, with lots of hop standing out, but yet not overly skewed to the bitter side. Nice fully satisfying palate.

Brownish color with tan head.  Decently malty with a fairly hoppy and earthy character.

On tap GABF 11

Bottle @ home. Reddish brown appearance with a big, carbonated, light brown head. Piney, organic, earthy hoppy,  caramel, toffee, moderately rich malty aroma. Fairly rich, moderately syrupy, dark caramel, toffee malty, moderately piney, bitter hoppy flavor. For the most part, this is smooth and fairly tasty.

12 oz. bottle at the STLHops Pinball Party. Vision starting to get cloudy. Glad we got the bigger name stuff out of the way early. Now Im just picking things off the table. Pours a nice amber color with a lasting beige head. Aroma of banana, sweet malts, earth, nuts, ripnened fruits, and winter spices. Flavor of sweet malts, brown sugar, banana bread, and more peppermint-cinnamon winter spice. Medium-bodied, with a malty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Good ESA, a style I havent had a whole lot of.

Not just a brew just for winter! This brew poured up a dark brown body with a sporty bubbly head with good retention and lacing effects on the glass.  Aromas of caramel, hops, malts, chocolate, coffee, dark fruits (plums, prunes).  Flavors of the same with a smooth clean finish full of chocolate and espresso.  There are also hints of fig and something akin to candied apples intermingled with all those flavors.  Medium-bodied and one that will definitely warm you up!

12oz bottle, originally from Specs.  I suppose it has been aged about 9 months, starting in the closet, then the fridge.  Pour is hazy dark amber with a tan-orange head that sticks around and laces.  Malty, hoppy, christmas-y aroma on first whiff.  Once sipped, the flavor is malt, spice & pine, with a warming alcohol finish.  Nicely balanced.  Taste swaps between bitter and sweet.  Yummy.  Just like I remember from Christmas time last year.  Guess it held up well.

While it has nothing to do with the beer, the label art is glorious on the 2010 release.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Rich reddish-brown with moderate tan head and some nice lacing.

Aroma: Caramel, cherry, toast and spicy English hops.

Taste: Caramel and wintry spice are dominant (even though no spices were added, must be the hops), with some cherry and fruity undertones. The strong spicy English hops build on the finish, and it becomes quite bitter. Great complexity from both malts and hops.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, somewhat creamy medium to full body, very dry finish.

Overall: Very good example of an English Strong Ale that has been ramped up on hops. The spicy, floral English hop bitterness is just slightly off-putting but this is still a very good, complex beer for the winter.
Tap. Pour is copper with an off-white head. Aroma caramel, dark fruit, and malty. Taste to match with a bit sourness to boot. Good beer.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.[ Trade by fiulijn ]. Clear dark brown amber colour with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, bread, caramel, fruity, dried fruit, moderate roasted, light chocolate and dusty chocolate, leather notes. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, dark sweet malt, chocolate, fruity. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110603]

Part of the 9hr epic solo drunkfest in Portland in Nov, 2010. CASK. Pint. Getting really wobbly and its only 4pm. Bad lighting in here - deep red? plenty tan head, small spots here and there. Huge malty nose, fruity, interesting spice - cinnamon and peppermint, candied orange rind, light alcohol. I like it because it is mellow and complex with no dominating characteristic to distract. Plenty of malty flavour, burnt caramel, weak coffee, herbal, cinnamon and maybe the faintest of clove, raisin. Medium bodied, almost no x-mas spice finish which is wonderful to enjoy this style of beer minus that distraction.
Velvety, malty, toasty and roasty.  Appearance is amber in color, thick with a small one finger head.  Super smooth and delicious.  Outstanding winter brew.

2009 vintage.

Pours a very cloudy deep dark copper color with dark amber hues when held to a light source and a one finger light beige that quickly settles into a lasting ring.

Sweet malty aroma with subtle spice, alcohol and dark fruit. Im picking up a buttery diacetyl presence that is slightly off-putting. Hints of caramel, biscuit and rye along with a subtle medicinal/herbal character and sweet dark fruit, especially cherry.

Medium bodied with a prominent peppery spice presence up front that lingers throughout over the sweet malt and dark fruit notes into a lingering dry finish. Slight herbal/medicinal with only a touch of the buttery character found in the aroma. Very malty with lots of caramel, biscuit, toffee, toast and rye. Im also picking up hints of cherry, raisin, plum and grape. Complex but a bit too heavy on the spices for my liking. The lack of booziness/heat helps drinkability but Im just not a big fan of the flavor.

Jubelale.  Taster into Sniffer glass at urge gastropub.  Light brown fast dissipating head.  Smells like a dark sweet winter lager.  Red brown caramel malts on the taste with a decent citrus piney hop flair.  No lacing.  Overall 8 of 10.

Appearance: deep rich mahogany hues under a khaki head with lots of lace. Head lingers as a thin film, broken in some areas.

Nose: spices, apples, plums, prunes. Chocolate in the back along with raisins and chocolate cake. Nutmeg, cinnamon, and brown sugar. Apple crumble and fig newtons which mingles with aforementioned spices. Subtle and soft. Christmas cake.

Palate: sweet and fruity than spiced and dry. Apples and plums. Each quaff is dry and spiced with hints of earth in the back  twigs and shrubbery. Grows drier as it warms, highlighting spices  nutmeg forward followed by cinnamon. No brown sugar. Pine cones.

Final Thoughts: quite tasty. I could drink this all the time any time, but it does speak of the holiday seasons, relaxing with my love in front of a crackling fireplace. Another winner from Deschutes Brewery.

Bottle from Brewery Creek, VancouverDark brown color; medium sized compact head. Mild aroma of roasted malt and roasted nuts. Good flavor of dark caramel with a touch of roasted malt; the final is a bit nutty, with refreshing hop, and drier mouthfeel. Quite good.

A dark mahoany that is almost clear, very dark in the middle. A huge light tan head rises about four fingers. There is great retention, half the head falls fass, but a full two finger frosting like cap stick around. GREAT lacing. Certainly looks the part...The aroma is ROUGH with a capital R. Way too sweet with toffee then plums and winter spice. It teases because at first its almost nice, but its inappropriately strong. Weirdly reminds me of Lime Gatorade, how?...The taste is equally poor. Its incredily light in taste after how strong the aroma is. The feel is way to light, almost water. The taste is light toffee, coffee, gatorade, with chalk and alcohol.

This is horrible and needs to be dumped, even more opening it
got a six pack of this beer.  pours from a 12oz bottle brown in color with a decent amount of carbonation.  smell of toffee, coffee,and even some hops.  The taste is dark and sweet.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle. Copper with minimal head. Nice aroma with some magic in it along with some dark toffee and hops. Dark burnt toffee, coffee, hops, alcohol. Smooth and light enough to quaff and not jus be labelled a sipper. Strong enough that sipping does increase the enjoyment factor. Nice alcohol and hop notes in a warm aftertaste.

2010

Ruddy brown with ruby notes and one finer of light tan head. Nose is rich and raisiny with lots of caramel and leather. Rich malt forward flavor with some burnt sugar and raisin, caramel and toasted grain in the background.

12oz bottle, poured into tulip, light frothing head, sweet caramel aroma, a bit of earthy grittiness to this one, this is a great little sipper, I would have loved a bit of hoppiness to balance it all out. But this is quite nice. I wouldnt mind sipping on this all Winter long.

Pours very dark but with bright red reflections in the light. Smells sweet, rich and chocolatey. Tastes creamy-smooth with a bitter swallow and finish.  Taste follows suit with the body although it tastes lighter than the beer looks and feels. Great winter ale, love the palate, would definitely drink it again!

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Whole Foods Austin.  The nose is powerful and fruity.  There is a slight metallic note, a bit of apple and grape, and a nice malty undertone.  It pours a clear, dark amber color with a large, frothy but sturdy light tan head.  Great head retention and nice lacing.  The flavor starts off malty but has a nice hop component to it.  Sort of British with an American twist.  Light pine notes and resin go with the bready and caramel malts.  Nice contrasts here.  Medium bodied with above average carbonation leading to a medium to long, slightly bitter finish.  Nice brew!

I always look forward to Jubelale. This years release really hits the spot for me with a little spice. Im not going to go overboard on the rating. There are plenty posts beneath mine. Bottom line, I like this beer.

Very dark amber pour with a big cream colored head. Aroma of caramel, milk, English hops and a leathery yeastiness. The flavor is a creamy sort of sweet with a touch of yeast and bitterness. Really smooth and creamy, and full bodied. Not much of a finish though. This is a good beer, but everything seems a little muted until you really let it warm up

12oz bottle.
Dark amber color with some off white head.  Caramel and dark fruit aroma - some hop bitterness.  Some spicyness and more dark fruit, hops arent as evident in the flavor.  Very tasty and drinkable - a winter seasonal I look forward to every year.
Pours a dark amber colour with a coffee  head which leaves a great lacing on the glass. The aroma is light sweet caramel. The taste is malty start with a smooth sweet alc finish

Bottle 2008 vintage thanks to Secret Santa. Copper-brown pour with large frothy head. Aroma of vegetables from the english hops and oxydation is a little bit off at first but the more you dig into it you get some burnt caramel and toffee, pleasant earthy notes and christmas spices. Flavors of caramel malts and a nice hop bite despite its age. Held off pretty well. Powdered cocoa. Quite pleasant.
Good winter ale! This beer pours great has a very strong taste to it. Strong head

2010 bottle.  deep dark red pour with a 1 finger off white head.  dark fruit aromas with some light cherries and raisins most prominent..... not that strong though - have to search in the glass for the aromas to hit the nose.  Once it warms, they come out a bit more.  medium to full body with sweet malts circulating throughout with more dark fruit (raisins, red grapes, plums, cherries and figs).  warming.  smooth throughout with a bitter finish followed by more sweetness.

Poured into a pint glass.

4.0 A: Dark amber color. Two fingers of creamy, but frothy head has average retention and leaves lots of lacing.

3.5 S: Caramel and dark fruits. Pleasant, but not nearly strong enough. I let this warm up for my final evaluation and it just simply wasnt packing any punch.

3.5 T: Tastes like what I can only describe as olde ale light. Dark fruits again, a healthy bitterness (perhaps too healthy), and caramel malts. Good, but perhaps too bitter for the style and the mouthfeel ruins the taste.

2.0 M: Light body, which is exactly what I dont want in a beer like this. Good carbonation. Not very creamy. Mouthfeel sucks.

3.0 D: Would not be bad at all if it had some body.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-13-2009 01:52:14

Bottle. Nose is cinnamon rolls, spice candy, and prunes. Pours a dark red-brown with a fine-grained, beige head that leaves lace. The flavor is very big and sweet -- more cinnamon roll, molasses, and the faint savory/soy overtone I usually pick up in this style. Carbonation is clean without being intrusive. Yum.
Bottle: Not a big fan of Winter Ales, this one has lots of fruit, malt, caramel and raisins. Full and complex finish with a strong alcohol kick. Food Pairing: Glass of Water, this has all you need!

Pours clear brown with a full, fluffy, lasting tan head. Aroma is of winter cheer and spices, almost piney too. Tastes lightly spiced, malted and not very hoppy. Medium-bodied with a crisp, smooth texture and average mouth-carbonation, Deschutes Jubelale finishes sweet and faint lasting dryness.

12oz bottle from blutt59, thanks Bob! Pours a deep brown colored body with a slight amber hue around the outside. Thin, fizzy, brown head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is sweeter caramels with a bit of a cherry fruitiness and some cocoa. A light earth and some spices come out more as this warms with a touch of bread and some more dark fruits. Flavor is caramel and brown sugar up front with more of a plummy dark fruit than the aroma. A pretty distinct spicing and hop bitterness comes in the middle and leads this into the finish. A touch of cocoa, some yeast, and a light bread join the ample caramel malts and spicy hops that make up a fairly high bitterness consisting of a mix of pines, earth, and wood. A bit of a toasty pie crust and cocoa increases ever-so-slightly in the hoppy, lengthy aftertaste following a smooth, medium-full body and very soft, somewhat tickling carbonation. Overall, a pretty cool beer. Lots of sweet, somewhat fruity caramels with a higher, spicier, fairly complex hop bitterness that maintains a solid balance throughout. I liked this one.

aroma- cherry, vanilla, sugar, bread, cinnamon, apple spice.  pours dark ruby brown with little head.  taste is dark roasted malt, spices, cinnamon, clove, some coffee, dark fruit, hints of chocolate, spruce, floral bitter hop finish. There is a lot going on in this one, nice flavors but maybe a little much. palate is spicy, full bodied, with maybe a bit too much carbonation.

(null)
Malt: roasty, caramel
Hops: pine, spruce
Yeast/Bacteria: dough
Other: butterscotch
Color: brown, orange
Liquid: clear
Head: tan, minimal
Initial: medium bitterness
Finish: light bitterness, light sweetness
Finish Duration: average, long
Body: medium
Texture: slick
Carbonation: average, soft
Finish: long, bitter

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2012 Clear dark copper, fine frothy tan head lasts. Strong aroma of dark roasted malts, some caramel. Bitter burnt roasted malt taste, some dark fruit, bitter hop background. Not too sweet. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Dry bitter finish. NFL (Not For Lagerboys)

Bottle, served in a pint glass. Poured a deep, dark brown with loose tan head. Aroma of fresh hops and roasted malt. Very fresh, pleasant floral and spicy hop bitterness balanced by chocolate, caramel malty sweetness. Not overly bitter or sweet. Excellent hop character and balance: a very good, very drinkable beer.

Pub Pint Glass. Aroma: caramel, cereal, dough. Color: brown, red, tan foam. Taste/Palate: medium bitterness, medium sweetness, full body, creamy, bitter, long finish. A great winter seasonal; this year Im trying to drink my way through the best Northwest US winter seasonals--this ranks top amongst them. Next up Full Sails Wassail!

$1.99/12 oz. brown bottle. Central Market. San Antonio, TX. The design on this 2010 bottle is awesome. Id like to see this in my fridge every year. A reddish brown beer with a small but nice head. The taste is caramel malt, sweet, dark fruits and is pretty smooth but not quite as good as the aroma

12 oz bottle into a pint glass: Its got a dark raspberry/ ruby tone as it sits beneath a tan pillow-top of foam in no hurry to dissipate. Still very cold. I suggest letting warm at least 5 minutes in the glass from the fridge. It smells sweet, like dried fruits, some caramel and candy sugar. With warming the flavor takes on some toffee/ bread-pudding/ plum notes, bittering upon the finish with a hint of alcohol. Its delicious.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark reddish brown color with an inch of tan head. The aroma is a strong dose of spiced bread and caramel malt paired with resiny hops and orange rind. The flavor closely mirrors the aroma with some additional roasted malt, hops bitterness and chocolate notes

The label is very paganistic. a Yuletide fire ringed with a string of hops.  The pour is a deep brown / orange, much like the heart of the flames on the label.  Very fruity aroma, like a XMAS fruit basket 2 weeks after the holiday,  It is a festival in the mouth!  Warming maltiness dances with hops around that Yule log.  Yet another treat from Bend!

2009 bottle. Hazy deep copper with a thick foamy beige head that leaves some lacing. Aroma of zesty pine, citrus, toffee and bread. The flavor is semi-sweet caramel malt with a smooth firm bitterness that really helps balance it out. Medium body with a soft carbonation and a slick mouth feel. Finally got around to rating this one, Ive been drinking this for years and its a great one, especially for the price. Very good fresh and ages pretty well too.

Bottle served in a snifter. Pours dark brown with amber tones. Medium sized light tan head. Good retention and lace. Medium aroma has mild bitter roast, spice notes, and dark fruit. Soft attack quickly bitters. Medium body, average carbonation, cricky texture. Strong oolong tea bitter finish. This might be a good with food or desert, but not something I would drink regularly during the season.

Dark mahogany pour with a tall, rocky, off-white head.  The aroma has deep tones of toffee, caramel and molasses with a hint of dark fruit and a nice resiny citrus hop balance.  The flavor shows lots of deep, semi-sweet toffee and caramel malt with some bitter black strap molasses, a little dark fruit in the middle and a nice long, piny hop bitterness on the finsih.  Dry, medium body with moderate carbonation.

Excellent winter beer that offers a lot for your palate.  While not an original beer, this has the balance of an old world beer as the large malt and large hop profiles are well blended and work well together.  I will definitely be trying this beer again.

Bottle. Poured into a tulip glass a dark, apple cider colored reddish brown with a fluffy 2 finger slighlty tan head. Sweet smelling, faintly of honey, along with caramel. Slight citrus hop notes in the nose as well. Medium mouthfeel with good carbonation. Very smooth flavored with notes of slight roast, some bitterness, and citrus. Some pine like bitterness as well makes itself known at the end. Slight lace on the glass. No real alcohol present in the nose or taste. Over all a nice beer but lacks any sort of in your face flavors but thats what is kind of nice about it too.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark reddish brown color with an inch of tan head. The aroma is a strong dose of spiced bread and caramel malt paired with resiny hops and orange rind. The flavor closely mirrors the aroma with some additional roasted malt, hops bitterness and chocolate notes. The mouthfeel is creamy and full-bodied with a dry, alcohol-warming finish. It has the hops kick of an IPA along with the roasty caramel malt characteristics of a strong Stout. Definitely one of my favorite Winter Warmers.
From a tap,white head,dark red,malty,pine flavor,this a pretty good xmas beer.

Dark ruby red with a tan head. Malty caramel aroma. Malty and sweet off the bat with a wee bit of bitterness, and as someone else described, a roasty biscuity finish. Didnt quite hit the spot for me.

Dark red color with a medium head.  Aroma of caramel and chocolate with a fair amount of graininess.  Strongly bitter taste.  Very earthy and spicy hop.  Very light caramel.  Its weird... smells like a great winter warmer, tastes more like a strong APA.

bottle.  Pours deep red ruby color with light brown, bubbly head.  Aroma of black cherry, caramel, brown sugar, raisin.  Big malty flavor with decidedly bitter finish.  Smooth, full bodied, creamy.  Caramel, hopped finish.  Simple, yet nice.
Smells like a hair salon. Looks like a porter. Tastes bitter and malty. Bubbly on the palate. Far from my favorite this season.

12 oz bottle from Princetons.  Dark brown pour with a couple of fingers of light tan colored head.  Nice caramel, malty aroma with a hint of spice.  Mouthfeel is a little thinner than I expected but the flavor is a nice balance of hoppiness and maltiness with a bit of caramel and a bit of nuttiness.

Bottle, thanks to both hobbersr and curly.Both of whom gave me a bottle within a single week. A man should count himself extremely fortunate to have such friends! Thank you my friends, you are both worthy as gentlemen and scholars! Pours medium to pale brown/reddish amber. Thin off-white head, spotty to poor lacing. Nose is soft buttery caramel, nice dark fruits, light red fruits, very slight notes of hop spiciness. A rather pungent and "spicebox" beer overall, despite a low hope presence. Flavours are rich and toffeed, solid dark fruits and dates throughout. Spiciness is pervasive through the finish. LOADS of dates and raisins. Watching Grumpy Old Men. Did you know that the guy playing Jack Lemmons father was the original Penguin during the Adam West Batman era? I didnt either!  I can see it now though. Damn I love that old man! 

"Does she have big thighs?"

"No."

"Then why havent you mounted her!?!"


Classic.
