Reddish brown brew ,tannish brown head.Nose is almost like a belgian strong ale.Strong aromas of dark fruits and roasted malts,very nice.This was a little cold at first and I was let down but after it had a chance to warm the flavor took on a major transformation.Dark fruit,ripe dates and cherries.Then the raosted malts came in changing the feel on the tongue.Indiana_Red,u da man.

Pours dark copper with little head.  Aroma is chocolate with some hops and alcohol.  Sweet with choclate, some caramel, toasted malts, with little hops and alcohol burn.  Creamy feel, nice aftertaste.  Overall an exceptional winter ale.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2006 2004 draught pint at Redbones.  Wonderful deep red with dark brown tinges, quite transluscent with a small off-white head.  Smells of sweet malt, light spicing (cinnamon) and lightly spicy hops that are very fresh.  Flavor starts out sweet and spicy with the hops being present but not bitter, just fresh and spicy.  Light toffee and toasted malt, sweet caramel and molasses on the finish with more herbal hops-like flavor.  Full bodied and delicious with a smooth, creamy consistency and very low carbonation.  Beautiful!  8/5/8/4/172005 draught pint at Redbones.  More crystal malt heavy with that profound hardness and a thick sugariness as well.  Cherries, tangerines and bitter oranges crowd the palate and seem at odds with the (rather acidic) roasty/toasty malts.  Seemed rather jumbled and in the end it goes from a bit too sweet, to too bitter without much room for in between.  Though there certainly is no skimping on ingredients and the overall texture was about the same as last year.  Rating is an average.  8/4/7/3/14

Foamy tan head on a clear amber/orange body. Sweet malt and bitter hop in the aroma with a nice roasted tone and light spices. Rather mild but nice and inviting. Flavor is a little thin but tasty. Sweet caramelly with hoppy tones and notes of chocolate and toffee.
Pours out nice dark brown color with a head.  Nice roasted flavor, kinda hoppy, warmth finish.  Perfect for cold winter day.

Jubelale pours a dark reddish brown with a brown head that quickly goes to a film.

Its aroma is sweet figgy chocolate with a little bitterness and molasses.

The flavor is roasted malts with some figs and chocolate and spices.  It has a nice bitter finish that balances it well.  The mouthfeel is very smooth and creamy, but a little acidic.

Overall, a very fine winter seasonal with some nice alcohol warming.  Reminds me of Great Divides Hibernation Ale.

Pours a dark brown with medium sized tan head.  Aroma of cherries, malt, oranges. Flavor is strong, malty warming feel.  Alcohol is there in the finish. Overall a very tasty winter warming beer. Thanks to Indiana Red for this tasty one!
Very deep amber in color. Aroma is sweet, roasty and malty. Flavor is fairly hoppy. Finish provides a roasty malt taste. Interesting combination of the hops and the roastiness.

Last of the shipment from Indiana Red.  
-sob-  Anyway, pours very thin with little head, and drinks a heavy smokey flavor.  Thinly spiced and hopped.  Not bad!
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: An amber beer with a huge orange head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of hops and hints of roasted malt. The flavor is sweet and very roasted, but also woody and with a dry hoppy finish.
Reddish coloured. Quite fruity and malty. Very sweet flavour. Not a bad beer, just plain boring.
Quite malty. Great beer in the beginning, but the finish is a bit thin and watery. Therefore it lacks complexity, which would make it much better.

Color of dark wood with rich, red highlights.  Dense, rich, fruity malt aroma with an underpinning of saturated, roasted caramel.  Bubblegummy malt flavor that appears in the aroma as well as it warms.  A big hop and deeply roasted component with a dark cherry yeast flavor and an omnipresent celery seed flavor persist.  I hate celery.  Get an Iron Duke from Wellinton County and compare thses two.
Malty aroma, sweet, some whisky. Brown body, ruby tint, with a nice off-white head. Very malty flavor, some hops. A bit watered out... Thank you flipbrewer for trading me this one!
Bottled: Amber coloured. Light brown head. Sweet, malts and some cocoa in the aroma. Flavour is grassy and hoppy with some cocoa/caramel notes. Is quite bitter in the end. Nice.

Mahogany.  A nice, equal combination of malt and hops in the nose providing fragrances of pine, deep rich malts, caramel and dark fruits.  Balance continues onward into the flavor.  Large, creamy malt flavor with notes of caramel, maple and dark fruit balanced by a cunning bitterness and hop notes of pine and other citrus flavors.  I like this stuff.

Dark mahogney color with a thin light brown head. Aroma of malts, dark fruits, with some hitns of licorice. Lightly sweet malts, some toasted charachter, hints of plum. Some woody and earthy notes. Dry bitter finish.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2012 Retasted Jan 2008 - 2007 edition. After living away for a couple of years I had some shipped. Not an ale for everyone, more bitter than most would like for a holiday. But since I have no 5s on my list, Im going to knock this up a little. Bottle. The 6.7 will warm you up in a hurry. Will be looking forward to trying this ale again.

Mar 2012 still really good. more malty than bitter.

woohoo! Jubelale is out!  Bottle: This years batch has a doughy, chocolate and piney aroma; the flavor is heavy on the malt, notes of chocolate, caramel, molasses, with a slight earthiness; moderately grapefruit bitterness, nicely balancing finish; full, rich flavor and mouth-feel. This is perhaps the best from this great brewery

Appearance: hazy, murky, but bright cherry-red color, lighter and transparent at foot and sides, beneath a great, creamy head of foam.
Aroma: instant rich, sweet maltiness, with fruity flavors, too, and slight nuttiness, but altogether wonderful, a true treat to drink in the nose!
Taste: abundant, and wonderful. with tasty malt, just enough hops, a medium body, and a flavor that ranks among the most delicious. Possessed of a thick, clinging, sweetness on the texture that hangs mightily on the palate and makes this winter ale a never-ending delight. Mmm, Mmmmm!
This one really hit the spot!

First appearance of the season for me. I love the nice balance between the spicyness of the hops and the sweetness of the malt. My initial impression is that this years batch is a notch up from last years. Could be my imagination but what the heck. This is gonna be a great winter warmer for me.

Best regards,
Bill

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2005 04 Bottle Pours a nice dark mahogany with a modest off white head that settles into a thin continous layer.  Aroma is a nice spicy rich combination of dark malts and hops. Flavors of wood, grass, hops and spicy goodness.  Feel is not particularly heavy but smooth and warming.  I can see how this is such a good winter brew.  After taste is a long drawn out new or green woody flavor.
Spicy and warm, brining the winter season instantly into focus. This is a great winter brew.
This is a welcome to winter indeed. I like this brew alot and always look forward for its release. Strong, heart warming ale. Hearty and cheerful. Nice one Deschutes!

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2004 Pours a darker brown color with a nice off-white head. Sweet malty hop aroma. Taste carries the malty hop balance through very well and ends slightly bitter. Nice caramel taste, with some nice spice, and has a nice smooth mouthfeel. Kinda overwhelming bitterness towards the end in my opinion.

EXACTLY like Full Sail's Wassail Ale, but more expensive.
Coca-cola colored, no head, medium fizz. Smells a bit like grapes and chocolate. A great balance of hops and malt. Bitter aftertaste lasts just the right amount of time. I'd gladly drink this beer all year long. It's all about the balance!

slightly cloudy mahogany color, nice thick white head, candy, yeast, malty, earthy, nicely hopped  pine, hints of grapefruit, toasty  caramel; flavor is good, well-hopped, pine and grapefruit, malty, a bit sweet, some fruit, decent texture, a good beer but nothing extraordinary

Bottle.  (Thanks Mike!)
Dark brown in color with a frothy tan head that strangled the glass with bands of Brussels Lace.

Nose is nutty, malty, with citrus, clove, cinnamon hints.

mouthfeel is nice and full.  Hard-edged hop character with grassy, piney acids.  Malt solid in background, caramel, cinnamon, nutmeg and clove.

Finish is moderate dry.
UPDATED: NOV 23, 2004 THis is a very spicey brew, the seasonal that comes out.  Another dang good one from deschutes.  Very creamy with lots of flavor.  One of deschutes better offerings
Deep red-brown.  Nose candy, Christmas toffee, smoky, deep plummy.  Very malty, sweet, molasses and raisins, bit sugary.  Good.
Mild spice, caramel, fruit and sweetness make this a nice treat. Very mild with a smooth finish.
Orange hue. Cascades hops aroma with honey and citrus. Lemon pie comes to mind at one point. Beautiful hops and citrus in mouth with rich smooth body.
(Bottle) Pours a frothy, beige head with a deep red body. Nose of tart cascade hops. Flavour is far maltier then the nose. I detected some raisin flavours in there. Good.

Hops and spices in the aroma.  Clear, extremely dark amber color with a medium size head.  I tasted some grapefruit and a touch of smokiness.  It had a little bit of carbonation and an alcohol feel, with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  A solid beer.

Color is a rusty orangish brown, moderately deep and clearish with a muted glow, medium smooth tannish head that sits breifly fading to a thick cream colored skim and lots of intricately woven sheets of lace. Aroma has a good caramel top with some underladen tones of dried fruits and hops. Taste is slightly sweet, mild overall with a super fine blend of calming dried hop variants, both dulled and mild fruityness and woodsy sense in the hops. Malts lend the sweetness throughout which come through as well rounded and help keep balance. Finish has a lingering mix of dried hops first then the sweetness returns for a stint eventually breaking away into some light earthy tones, kinda nice in that department. But overall the flavors are short lived and not all that complex, seems a bit one dimensional, if it weren't for the finish this would have been average for me I think. Its very well balanced, but I was looking for more of a boost in the flavor dept. Slight chocolate tones show up as it warms which is a nice surprise.Feel is close to medium body with an overall light sweet twinge and mild dryness thats always mixing and giving way to one another. Pretty decent, good balance, but lacking some boldness and depth of lasting flavors, that said, it still makes for a good sessionable Old Ale, quite drinkable; the 6.7% may be a bit much for many of these though.
dark body with a tan head.  very soft with a good fruit texture, some sweet carmel malts and a good hop balance.  Very nice.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2007 2006 vintage. In the bottle from Wilburs. Dark brown with a super creamy head that pours much more like concrete than beer foam. Aroma has a great scent of aromatic hops yielding a pine forest/citrus-like aroma. Smooth for a 6.7% abv ale. Biggest thing to note is the monstrous fruity flavor. This is like drinking a can of fruit cocktail. The finish hangs a long roasty bitterness on the tongue long after you are done with the beer. Really liked this much better than the first time that I had it when I rated it a 3.4!

Dark brown in color with orange edges.  Nice frothy head.  Aroma was like a bowl of nuts and hops....fruity notes.  Aroma was nice, but this beer blew its wad and faded once the flavor came around....too thin, just caramel and some spice.
This is a great English Strong ale.  Hoppy, malty, and pine flavors.  Finishes clean, smooth, and crisp.

Pretty standard winter seasonal styled beer except for that *oh, this is definitely a Deschutes beer* quality that is just inescapable.  Not so sure that really works with this one, but it's a decent beer nonetheless.  Label is cool and I love the pour and color.  Pretty sweet, even for a warmer, but Deschutes does warn you that it will be.

dark brown color, with beige head.  Head lingers a while.  Hoppy sweet nose, malty with amber overtones.  Good flavor.  Mix of hops and malt is refreshing and well balanced.  Like IPA meets Oktoberfest.

From bottle. Pours brownish ruby with tall tan foamy head that lasts forever. Aroma is fruity hops.  Flavor is same with long bitter malty finish.  Not as many spices as some winter ales.  Seems watered down a bit with oily/watery mouthfeel.  Alcohol is not evident in flavor.  Ironically, not as good as what I tend to expect from Deschutes. Perhaps it's better on draught.

Good seasonal.  Flavor is malty with the typical spicy blend of a holiday ale.  Slightly roasted with hoppy spicy finish.  Head retains nicely and leaves some lace.  As far as holiday ales go, I'll buy this again.

Dark amber color,small off white head,that faded fast to leave a small amount of lace behind.Malty,caramel aroma with hints of hops and mild fruit.Malty taste with a little caramel and mild fruit,lightly spicey and fairly hoppy.The alcohol does manage to show itself upfront but later fades.The after taste is a nice bitter hop with a slight alcohol hint.Very nice brew and even nicer that i have a few more for later.Well worth finding this brew if you can.

The body is a deep garnet that sparkles when held up to the light. The head is a beautiful light tan, rocky, and clings to the sides of my glass tenaciously. The aroma makes my mouth water, caramel malty sweetness dominates with loads of spicy hops just beneath. This stuff smells real nice. The flavor is no disappointment. A crisp sweetness is perfectly balanced by a good dose of spicy bitter hops. The body is a perfect medium full with a perfect semi-bitter finish. Wow this is one of the better Winter brews out there! Damn I wish Deschutes was available in my area. Many thanks to my brother, diegogator, for this bottle (and the other 10 west coast winter seasonals plus a bottle of AleSmith Barrel Aged Speedway that he sent for a XMas present.) I bet you are jealous of my wonderful brother! ;)

Complex spicy aroma that draws one's mind to coriander, caramel, and hops.  This is an exception winter brew that quickly warms the soul.  Smooth and crisp with a subtle bitter flavor.  Dark amber red brew with a tannish white head. Poor lacing but an excpetional flavor that lasts.  This is a very tasty winter beer.

Nice well balanced aroma of malt, alcohol, spice and some hops. Deep mahogony color that is slightly hazy. Not sure if this is bottle conditioned or not. A little yeast at the bottom of the bottle would lead me to believe that it is, but there really isn't enough for me to be sure. Light carbonation with a dense, creamy tan head. Taste profile is malty at the beginning, with a nice hop flavor coming in at the middle. A spiciness from the hops leads the finish, which is quite balanced and complex. Quite a big bodied beer, the finish is long and warming. Quite a nice beer to have on a cold Friday evening. Well done!

Bottle

Clear garnet with a determined tan head that completely restores with a good swirl. I get caramel, leafy hop, apple, pineapple, pear, faint roasted malt, spicy alcohol, and earthy yeast on the nose. Quite candyish in aroma. The flavor begins with a reasonably complex blend of the fruits from the nose, caramel, and leafy hops. Midway, a bit of alcohol adds a touch of warmth, then a wave of green hops, roasted malt, burnt fruit, and smoke finishes it off. Almost sweet and candyish towards the end despite it all. Some spice, earth, and tree bark appear in the aftertaste. Medium in body, with a mouthfeel that is washed clean after each sip by the dryness of the alcohol. Overall, a very good winter warmer that I could enjoy each winter. My thanks to Gromit for the bottle.
A tasty english strong ale.  Nice reddish brown color.  Taste is slightly malty.  A very sweet and bitter finish.  Very good winter.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2010 Deep brown with ruby-red highlights; lasting off-white head; beautiful lace patterns. Super smooth on the tongue. Meaty but not heavy. Nicely balanced: sugary and toasty, caramel-laden malts with some zingy hops. Nice amount of bitterness in the aftertaste. Flavorful, festive and cozy beer.

You've seen this, tasted this and enjoyed this before ... it's good but it's also something packaged for the holidays.  Medium taste with no kick but it has that "sneak up on you later feel" ... you know the kind that makes you call the cab for a ride home after 2 of these.  Buy some on the way to a party ... your host will appreciate it.
Subtle hops with roasted malt flavor. Frothy head, medium palate. Nice start to my stop in Oregon last weekend.
Hops and toasted malts blend in the nose.  Beer pours a gorgeous red/brown.  Hops fight to get through the thick, roasty malt flavors, finally finish with a good wampf of bitterness.

2003~ hoppy aroma, looks like maple syrup with a creamy head, nice dense creamy mouthfeel, complicated flavor, hops, roasted malts, maple syrup, good finish and lingering flavor, beats Bridgeport's Ebeneizer.

2003 - Pours a deep ruby color with a nice creamy tan, quickly dissipating, head. This beer also has nice lacing.  Aroma is rich, sweet and fruity.  Wow, this tastes really good!  Wonderful malt sweetness and some chocolate.  Also some hop bitterness...this is very well balanced.  Medium body and slightly chewy.  An excellent winter brew.
pretty fruity taste and i can almost taste a hint of almond and some spices this is a great winter warmer..you'll like it if your a freak like me

2003 - This was very nice, and exquistely balanced, extremely easy to drink.  I love Deschutes, I have never not enjoyed anything I have had from them.  Pours a very nice copper, ruby-esque color with a small craggy head.  Nice malty aroma and taste, with just enough hops to be satisfying.  Lots of caramel, and a light bit of chocolate is also present.  A very nice seasonal.
2003 release. Nice dark reddish color with a medium head. Fair amount of malt flavor. Hints of caramel, hops and toffee. Slight bitterness that blends well with the sweetness. A nice seasonal.

Ok my first sight ( and purchase of course) of a winter seasonal and thank goodness its my favourite.
Comes in the typical Descutes 12 oz bottle..nice simple label..of a poinsetta bordered window looking out to a starry winter sky.
Poured into my British imperial dimpled mug..this is a beauty of an ale..Garnet coloured with a nice sized coffee n' creme coloured head..that goes but leaves nice lace.
Lovelly strong aromas of malts ( coffee) and of wine!..very nice.
The taste is nice too not too over powering at all..nice smooth malt sweetness with a small hop bite and a hint of warming alcohol as it hits the throat.
Very delicious and utterly smooth and creamy on the palate.
A very nice winter ale..not to strong on the alcohol..but definatlly the smoothest on the market

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2004 2003 vintage tasted fresh:
Pours with a light brown head.  It is a deep brown color.  As it pours I get notes of raisin and roasty malt aromas, perhaps a hint of banana as well that might be a hop contribution (really hard to tell).  There is quite a bit of fruity - spicy hops in the aroma that seems to have a candy coating.  This beer is quite smooth, a finish that is reminiscent of rum.  Quite good, complex.  Has a finish that is of roast malt and an astringent / slightly alcoholic ending, as well as some balancing hop bitterness.  Fruity notes of raisin and cherry are evident as well.  A very well balanced beer with some hop character as well, some hop spiciness definitely hits my tongue, though it is subdued.  The aroma is the best part of this beer, it is not quite perfect but it is close.

Prunes and brown sugar. Dank and musty with brisk, swirling hoppiness. Aromas of dried flowers, gourmet soy sauce, and plums! Leaves a rich, warming, creamy dark bitterness in the back of your throat. Delightful, and to be consumed slowly and savored.
yum nice and harty and very warming the perfect effet of a celebration ale its red amber hue shows great color and the head is frothy and thick
A fresh hop aroma with a well rounded body and nice lacing. Alcohol is detectable and the malt adds a nice musky fruit aroma. This is a very nice winter beer.

Pours a dark reddish brown with a thick creamy tan head that hangs on forever and laces nicely.
caramel malt aromas, with some citrus in the background .
Flavors are sweet malty, citrusy, bitter, spicy. Nice long spicy bitersweet finish.

I'm slightly new to the beer arena, but christmas/winter ales in the first week of October....? Heck I'm still trying to enjoy all the pumpkin ales and Octoberfest/German brews. Oh well I can't
complain. Living up here in the northwest I
have more quality beers to choose from than you could shake a stick at. Literally. Now to the beer. Pours a medium-dark reddish brown with a beautiful tan head that slowwwwly diminishes. The nose of this beer is really nice. Spicey gingerbread sweet. Carbonation seems to diminish along with the head. Very rich, tasty
malty beer that is balanced perfectly by the hops. A must try for anyone
UPDATED: FEB 9, 2004 Wow, I was really impressed with this.  Caramel-candy like smell, nice head, dark red almost brown, nice hops at the end.  Tastes like cherry candy.
Pours deep ruby with some head and a bit of lace.  Sweet candied malt aromas.  Caramel and candy flavors with a bit of hop for a finish.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2011 tap-tucson beer fest
Nice old ale!!!  this one has it all.  a great balance of hops, spice, huge malts, smoke and spice.  very resin-y-some citrus at the very finish.  nicely done!!

Rerate-bottle 2010 vintage-pours deep crimson red with a lite kacki soapy head with some lacing.  nose of burnt malt, noble spicy hops, lite pine, smoke, char.  Flavors of char, wood, pine/earthy hops with a lingering burnt note through the whole way.  I dig this even though its not a style i drink on a regular basis.  Long burnt finish with some lingering spicy hops.  Very solid beer and one of the best from this brewery.

After having the Double Bale Quail, the Jubel appears to be the weak little cousin.  This has a lot of malt and a bit of hops.  Slips of coffee, caramel sweets, chocolate and citrous.  More sweet than bitter, but the combination of flavors isn't that interesting.

Had this in the bottle, pretty damn good; had it from the cask and my god what a seasonal ale. I was in Portland for Thanksgiving at some fish n' chips joint and I truly could not have had a better beer. The color was like a sunset, all red and orange and opaque; off the cask it had nearly no head (but out of the bottle it's small bubbles and tight). This brew was redolent with so many different hop notes and a rich, malty, ester-ridden bouqet that I literally sat with my nose in the glass for about 2 minutes. Bold, sweet, malty flavor, citrus hoppiness came in at the beginning of the aftertaste and was followed my another, different onslaught of malt, reminiscent of unfermented wort. Can't quite tell if the subtle spice notes are adjuncts or hops. A true test of a beer's meddle is tasting it from the cask. Jubelale is a champion.

This one pours a muddy red and orange with a slightly tan and orange head which lingers here and there around the glass. The aroma is predominantly caramel malt with peaches, something very slight in spice (coriander?) and a hint of alcohol sweetness. The taste is predominantly fruity in nature..grapefruits and peaches mixed with caramel sweetnesses near the ending. Very bittersweet citric ending, nice however. Ive never been a true lover of christmas ales, but this does a decent job in not spicing me to death. High alcohol content is well hidden, relative to other christmas beers. Thanks goes to beerguy101.
On tap.Fruity caramel aroma.Reddish brown appearance.Chocolate caramel,fruity peach flavor.Mild hop chocolate finish.
Thanks to Gregory for this bottle. Good solid seasonal. Not enough spice flavor for me. Nothing wrong with it.

Bottle at RAF: Golden copper with a lacey head and blossoming hop aroma.  Sweet caramel flavor with good complexity and smoothness.  Soft, lightly bitter finish rounds out a drinkable, well-brewed ale.
RAF: Deep amber with a hoppy nose.  Good malt/hop balance.  Very drinkable and refreshing.  Citrus, moderate bitterness.  A decent brew.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2013   Dark fruit aromas. Fruity/banana combines with a dark caramel malt flavor. Smooth finish gains an element of burnt coffee and just a hint of earthy vegetable, well balanced through the medium length. A very flavorful and enjoyable strong ale but lacks a sense of fullness.

Pours out of the bottle a dark, murky amber color with an attractive, off-white head.  Nice brown sugar, cinimon toast taste.  Nice bitterness in the finish.  Very nice drinking winter seasonal.  I only wish I could get it locally.
It's a pity that they only release this wonderful ale seasonally. It probably ranks at the top of my favorites from Deschutes' offerings.
One of the best smelling beers I have ever encountered.  Great look, great taste with a winter kick, an awsome beer.

You'd think that after have a Sam Adam's Cream Ale, this one would mow me down like a John Deere.  It didn't.  To me it tasted like a watered down porter with some sugar added.  It has some malt to it.  Somewhat bitter on the finish.  I think I'm missing something.
Ruby color with off white head. Straw, fruit cocktail, cocoa in the nose. Sweet fruit, malty, pine flavors, complex and tasty for sure but a bit overcarbonated for me.
2002: Malty, slightly buttery aroma.  Malty, gingery/rhubarb flavour with a bit of a bitter finish.
First one I"ve had in 7  years.  Not as well balanced as I remebered it, but still a great beer.

Extremely hoppy aroma that leaves me drooling and waiting impatiently to taste it.  Its hop flavor backs up the aroma.  It has somewhat of a sweet malty taste to it.  Nice almost tan head.  It has a reddish-brown coloring that is pleasing.
Dark reddish brown, good head formation. Vanilla/banana aroma, mild spice. Caramel and banana custard flavor with a balancing nutty and roasted dryness. Nice complexity and balance.

Subtle hop aroma with a primarily malty character.   The taste is balanced with the carmel malts being most pronounced.  The hops are mild and complex but do not dominate the taste much like a typical English-style ale.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2013 Cask: Wonderful fruit and floral aroma, containing strawberries, cherries and spices.  Taste is more of burnt wood with dark fruit.  Very robust, with a syrupy palate and a nice burnt finish. 9/4/8/4/17 Bottle: Medium brown/orange head, dark amber color.  Smells fruity, almost like Life-Savers.  Tastes like peach, very light on the tongue.  Seems like a very nice holiday beer. 7/4/7/3/14

Nice cherry-red glow with light tan head that is nice but fades incompletely. The aroma is oranges, mild winter spiciness (whether its added or not) and a light, sweet malt. The first sip is a shock at the amount of hop bitterness. The hops seem to float seperately from the rest of the beer which is a warm soft sweet maltiness. The hop bitterness fades as you get used to it but it still seems out of place and unbalances the beer.
This is a descent brew, in the same malty tradition of their other brews.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2005 Too many different years with too many different tastes to add comments.
This is different each year, I confirmed that with the brewery, should be able to rate each year. just like Anchor
Darker brown color. Sweet spicy nutmeg(?) then a hoppiness kicks in.
Warming.  Front is very sweet - I was worried, but middle and finish are roasty, hoppy and dry.  This is my kind of winter warmer
Glowing ruby color. Huge maltiness in the flavor...some pine tones, floral hops, sweet fruit. Nice warming brew for the holidays.

Smells like a freshly poured glass of orange juice, yet in the background you get whiffs of a nutty malt overtone. The top is a creamy beige micro bubble soup the thins ever so slowly. The body is a lovely glowing dark reddish magenta. Subtle hints of cherry and bittersweet chocolate starts it off, then blends into an understated orange and flowerery hop bitter in the end. This an interesting tasting experience and shows quite a bit of skill in blending together several different subtle spices and flavors.
Light on the malt with a slight bitter aftertaste. Brew had a decent head and light evergreen aroma.
Clear copper red body with minimal head.  Aroma is sweet, slight pine, malty.  Taste is sweet and piney.  Smooth and English-style.

(8Dec2002-on tap) Excellent, novel beer.  
While I had never heard of this beer before, it undeniably it looked appetizing; blood red
with an extremely fine, frothy head.  The aroma lured
me further: SUPER MALT, bready, with healthy notes of aromatic hops.
Oh, but when it hit my lips...I was in heaven.  
It conjured up memories of the outlandish and wonderful 
homebrews of my college days.  Ahhh.  Super malt,
balanced perfectly with bittering hops, and with
the alcohol hidden very effectively.  Dont miss this 
beer if you find it!  Im surprised to see it called
an English Strong Ale.  Whatever it is,
malt lovers will especially appreciate it.
Very malty, and a cinnamon aroma and flavor dominate. Finishes with a pleasent piney, reiseny hoppiness.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 Bottle (2011 vintage). Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark amber-brown. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain/bread, caramel, nuts), lightly to moderately hoppy (grapefruit, apricot, resin), lightly yeasty (dough), with notes of black tea and marshmallow. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation.  Nice texture, aroma, and appearance, but as always this one is just too tart and unbalanced in the mouth.

Dark red-orange in color with a pretty good looking/lacing head. Caramel aroma highlighted by yeast (dough + cereal), and a resiny hop component. Sweet. Roasted flavors come out during the taste. Caramel/roasted finish and a bitter aftertaste. Medium body plus the refreshing bitterness make this brew fairly drinkable.

2002: Primarily chocolate and caramel malt aromas, along with slight higher alcohol aroma. Reddish-brown with a slight haze. Low carbonation, thin body. Good head with some lacing. Fruit, chocolate, and caramel flavors  present up front, with little to no perceptible hop bitterness at this point. Has a slight sweetness, but finishes quite dry, where a lingering, mild hop bitterness overpowers the malt. Sticky hops leave behind a thin film of  resiny bitterness on the tongue and lips. Alcohol well-masked. Seems aged already. For an English strong, I would have preferred more body, robust flavors, and alcohol. Seemed more like an underhopped American amber with some chocolate malt.

Dense, thick head on top of a deep mahogany body.  Brussels lace like theater curtains.  Sourish cherry or green apple aroma.  additional fruits and spices help to fit the seasonal theme well.  Also a kind of roasted nutty finish.  damn good beer.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2005 2005 - Firstly, we really need to split each annual vintage out into separate beers; they are different recipes and the labels are different. Roasted malt aroma with some type of spice I couldnt identify, but doesnt smell overly holidayish. Clear, ruby red incolor with a large, light tan, almost yellow head. Beautiful. Lots of visible carbonation. Looks Christmasy. Excellent lace. A little overly malty, but by mid glass, the hops come out. Initially, the alcohol profile appears too pronounced, but it mellows at mid glass. Some buterscotch creaminess; not sure if its from diacetyl, but it is nicely done, and really essential to its being a solid holiday beer. 2001 - Moderately malty, heavily hoppy nose with hints of flowers and perfume. Small, creamy, frothy, light-brown head. Excellent brussels lace, although the head mostly diminishes. Dark, black-cherry red body. Moderately sweet with moderate to heavy bitterness. Malt tones are also prevalent, making for a very well balanced brew. Vaguely reminscent of a cherry lambic. Great artsy label; a very good beer overall, though not as good as the SNCA. Ar 8, Ap 4, Fl 8, Pa 4, Ov 17, Ttl 4.1

Aroma is sweet and slightly medicinal with hoppy tones...The color is a fine mahogany with a medium head and fine speckled lace...Flavor is a complex bittersweet marriage of sweet and roasted malts, well-blended hops and a light, aromatic spiciness...Carbonation is kept light, adding just the right amount of sparkle...Body is medium-full...This is extremely well-balanced, with a robust flavor profile...This is in the upper echelon of winter seasonals...
Delicious x-mas beer, sweet and malty with pronounced hop bitterness with a spicy, floral finish. Changes from year to year, but always pleases
Deep dark color, with spice aroma.  Big hit of molasses, more so than years past.  Nice little bite on the end also.  I have to say I like it better than the 2001, but not the 2000.
Syrupy sweet aroma: corn syrup, molasses, hints of spice and spruce.  Flavour is even better - good amount of ethanol, some spice, a bit smokey, nice and malty.  Great for the style.
Mud brown in color with a tannish head that fades away all to quickly. Soft aromas of chocolate and nutmeg. Full malty body with flavors of cocoa, cinnamon and a subtle hop bitterness.
Brown pour until you hold it to the light. Pretty garnet heart thick tan head. Nice malty nose. Nice balance, a little spiciness. Malty with a clean hop bite coming through near the finish.
beautiful ruby color w/ a medium tan head. Nice carmel nose initially w/ a well balanced flavor of some hops & lots of malt. thx beerguy

You gotta love that nice crusty foam this beer leaves behind. The malt smells wonderful in this beer, it tastes great too. Deep molasses, mild caramel and hops. Palate is very nice due to the malt and the hops keep the Northwest feeling alive. This is a very good beer, and satisfies that ever so specific need I have for warming malt in the wintertime. Who needs firewood when you have this to warm your belly...seriously.
Great strong aroma and dark red in color.  The head is frothy and warms my stomach.  This is a good solid beer.

Malty flavor that tingles in your mouth and moves through different motions of taste in waves.  It is real sweet and hoppy at the same time.  The alcohol comes through clearly beneath all of the flavor.  Gorgeous red hue, solid head, strong body.  Buy it and enjoy.  Yum!

Rerate. Numbers are for the 2002 vintage. Deep ruby color, medium foamy head. Rich malt aroma. Tastes very different from the 2001 edition. Rich malt flavor, molasses, spices and spruce. Not as hoppy as the 2001. Chocolate malts and a touch of banana and clove. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste us slightly bitter. Nice and warming. Great for winter evening sipping.  2001 release. Red brown color, medium head. Medium bodied brown ale, nice mild roasted malts. Somewhat hoppy. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is malty and somewhat bitter.Nice and warming. Spiciness mellow with aging. Nice beer.
Nice maltiness with a big hop bite.  You can definitely taste the caramel throughout.  A very enoyable Strong Ale, which should age very nicely with time.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2008 A strong, seasonal ale with a nice amber-red color, fruity aroma and fairly smooth taste, though a little flat. Rerate: Akin to a harvest ale/strong ale with its pronounced hoppiness in aroma and flavor. Excellently balanced and smoothened candy malt that is almost, but not quite approaching syrup in consistency. = 3.4 rating.
Rerate: 2007 - Wow! This recipe must change dramatically each year. This is by far the best rendition yet. Amber-orange and small head, a nice looking beer. Unexpectedly spicy-hoppy aroma. Not sure if this is from the hop varieties or from the addition on spices. It melds into the brew extraordinary well, adding delicious complexity in aroma and flavor. Some citrusy notes appear giving way to piny resiny hoppiness, reminiscent of Laconners Tannenbaum Ale. Quite pleasing. Would love to get the recipe.Alcohol is not noticeable as this brew is expertly balanced to create a pure pint full of liquid craftmanship.
This is delicious.  I love the spiciness, spruce flavors.  I love how it warms you up.  I think this is one of the best winter beers out there.  Highly reccomended.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2004 This stuff is awesome. Great hops, great pronounced bitterness that doesn't overcome the rest of the beer. Very palatable even for people who have been drinking bud their whole life. 6.7% is nice too. I will drink this stuff until I can't get it anymore, and then save some 6ers for summertime. Nab this beer if you can find it. ReRate 2004: I have one of these from last year that I layed down. Still very carbonated. Aroma is all malt, dry and chocolaty. Excellent mahogany color. Taste is a little off. Still malty with caramel notes, some chocolate malt. Slightly oxidized, but not bad. Drying finish. I would say that this beer does improve with age, but not much.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2006 Rating #1 Bottle of the 2002 release (8 5 7 3 15).  Mahogany red color with a brown head.  A cherry and red fruit aroma.  A creamy almost sticky palate and a flavor of fruit and chocolate.  Rating #2 - Bottle of the 2001 vintage sampled in May 2003 (8 5 8 4 17).  A very dark red color that looks brown unless held directly to the light.  The nose is great with lots of deep fruits, caramel, and plums.  Chocolate, vanilla and oak in the flavor.  Well hopped but not a pronounced characteristic of the beer.  The nose of a good barley wine with a slighly weaker body and much of the same flavor.  Rating #3 Bottle of the 2006 release (12/8/06) (7 3 7 3 16).  A dark reddish brown color with a light brown head.    A cherry fruit and malt aroma with nice hints of sour.  Smooth, medium body, caramel malts and mild earthiness.
On par with the ebenezer ale but nothing special. Lighter in body and color than I would like. Not enough abv either.
great color with some sediment, lasting sweet alcohol throughout, huge fan and a great buy for safeway
Fruity, with a great finish.  Cant wait to have more.  GABF 2002
Bottle GABF 02: Light flowery hops aroma, orange/red color with a good head, light bitter ending.  A lot of other stuff and I know that this one is worth getting it again.  A unique ale for sure.
GABF 2002: Cloudy amber.  Rich piny citric earthy hops and caramel malt.  Rich fruity flavor.  Strong and alcoholic.
Nice toffee flavors predominate.  smooth, well-integrated beer.  Some lingering bitterness at the end.
Nice aroma and different hops flavor. Pretty calm for a winter ale.

Of all the winterbrews, this is perhaps the easiest for everyone at the party to enjoy.  Id almost call it the candy winter brew, because the fruity, flavorful taste almost borders on a simple malt beverage, but the hops quickly return it to the beer catagory.  I wont buy it in cases next year, but Ill get a couple bottles to enjoy.
This just doesnt do it for me. Is it my imagination or do I taste juniper berry in there?
I liked it, but its not my favorite seasonal of Northwest beer.
Nice winter brew.
Amber colored with a beige head. Malty aroma with hop notes. big hop flavor and bitterness. Good work on this beer!
This is a winter seasonal strong ale.  Very high alchy content, and noticable.  Good malty flavor with a hint of hops.  A nice warm me up.
A yummy seasonal brew though the taste varies ever so slightly from season to season.

The aroma is a hoppy, dusty old books, strong pine, chocolate.  If that looks like an incredible mess of aroma, Id agree but Im finding it appealing with some challenged glee.  Ooh this is nice... Challenging and good. The feel rocks -- soft and round. Slightly astringent finish. This is a much more appealing proposition for a winter warmer than a spiced brew for me. And this goes great with itself.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2014 Beautiful glowing ruby color. Thick and sticky off-white foam.  Very nice aroma of dates, phenols, and fruitcake.  Cherry candyish and great balance of dryly earthy malts and forceful hop bitterness.  Is this still bottle-conditioned?
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: This is my favorite winter warmer brew.  Unique chocolate-covered bananna flavor, with tons of malt and a surprisingly strong fush of hops at the end. The perfect beer for a cold winters night.

Holiday seasonal strong ale, with a good balance between citrusy flavours, flowery hop; malt; and a 
soft fruitiness (apple, pear).

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2003 Release (2003)

Draught @ Papago: This magnificent beer pours a transpicuous deep burnished copper color, the head mastodonic in size, spumescent in texture, and the color a winsome tan color, as the head deliquesces, a satiny sheet of lace forms to caress the glass. Big malt laden nose, caramel candy sweet, hints of the hops lay just beneath this delight for the senses, ambrosial start, nicely malt laden; the top has a moderate feel to the palate. Finish is agreeably carbonated, the hops spectacular in their spicy presence, nice droughty aftertaste that lingers on the palate. Each year I await the release of this beer like a kid waiting for his new Christmas bicycle and thanks to Papago Brewery, my most favorite Beer Palace, and Deschutes Brewery one of my top three favorite breweries, I get a double barreled treat, draught and bottles to store away, well we will see how long they stayed stored, the Vegas Line say that the odds are 10 to 1 against them lasting till the next release.
